Indian Affairs. (RG 10, Volume 6419, file 855-8, part 1)

PUBLIC ARCHIVES ARCHIVES PUBLIQUES CANADA
Campbell River, B.C.,
August 26th, 1947.

Indian Agent,
Alert Bay, B.C.

Dear Sir:

I was able to secure a small cabin belonging to Miss Thulin at Fifteen Dollars per month.

As there were no dishes or cooking utensils, I have bought just enough for my immediate needs, also a cot and mattress, at the Pioneer Hardware charged to the Indian Dept. I paid the rent in advance myself.

The cabin is really too small and there is some hitch about connecting the lights and there are no conveniences, so hope the house building will begin soon.

Do you know what salary I am to receive here?

I hope I have not overstepped my authority in doing these things. But the housing situation is desperate here at present.

Yours truly,

"Mrs. Constance Culver"
Alert Bay, B.C.,
Sept. 2nd, 1947.

EX'D.

Indian Commissioner for B.C., Department of Mines and Resources, Vancouver, B.C.

The attached letter has been received from Mrs. Constance Culver, newly appointed teacher at Campbell River Indian Day School, and will be self-explanatory.

This copy is being forwarded so that you will be kept in touch with what is transpiring at Campbell River, and also know of the housing problem we have on our hands at the present time.

Enc.

(M.S. Todd)
Indian Agent.

c.c. - Indian Affairs Branch,
Ottawa, Canada.

Indian Affairs. (RG 10, Volume 6419, file 855-8, part 1)
Indian Affairs Branch, Department of Mines and Resources,
Ottawa, Canada.

Attached is voucher #619, dated Dec. 4th, in the amount of $88.61, made payable to Mrs. Constance Culver, Campbell River, B. C.

When Mrs. Culver was employed as teacher of the Campbell River Indian Day School her salary included accommodation; but as no teacherage was provided by the Department, Mrs. Culver was obliged to find accommodation elsewhere and the only thing available in Campbell River was an auto camp. In addition to cabin rent, Mrs. Culver has had to pay for electricity and water.

I would recommend that Mrs. Culver be reimbursed for the rent of the cabin, electricity and water.

J. C. Letcher
Acting Indian Agent.

Encs.

Indian Affairs Branch, Dept. of Mines & Resources, Ottawa.

Your file 156-7-5 (WT 1)
Re: Mrs. C. Culver - Campbell River Indian Day School

I refer to Mr. Neary's letter dated December 18th with attached vouchers for payment of accommodation for the above named teacher. At the time of Mrs. Culver's appointment it was expected that a teacherage would be constructed at Campbell River from materials at the Port Hardy Army Camp. However, the builders were unable to complete the construction and in fact the work on this building has only just begun.

In view of the fact that it is apparently not the policy of the Department to supply water and light it is recommended that Mrs. Culver be re-imbursement for rent of the cabin, amounting to $77.00. The Department will no doubt be called upon to pay rent for accommodation for Mrs. Culver until such time as the teacherage is completed.

D. M. MacKay,
Indian Commissioner for B.C.

The attached voucher #380, dated March 31st, 1949, in the amount of $65.52, payable to Hughes Bros., Campbell River, B. C., is in connection with the water system at the Campbell River Teacherage.

For the Department's information, when the Surveys and Engineering Branch installed this water system, the pipes were laid only a few inches under the ground, with the result that the entire system froze up this winter. As it was an emergency I hired Hughes Bros., plumbers of Campbell River, to make the necessary repairs. It was necessary for them to dig up all the pipe from the Teacherage to the Pump House, which is some three hundred feet, thaw out the pipes, dig a trench of the regulation depth for the pipes, and relay all the pipes and make the connections. They also insulated the pipe where necessary, and installed new pipe where the old pipe had been damaged by the frost.

Encs.

(M. S. Todd)

Ottawa, May 22, 1936.

Dear Sir:

I have your letter of the 30th ultimo, relative to the establishment of a summer school at Noblerly Lake and enclosing a list of the equipment required.

The Department withheld reply to your letter until an opportunity was obtained of discussing the matter with His Lordship the Bishop of Grouard. He has approved of a school being conducted for approximately a three or four month period during the coming summer. It is noted that the Provincial authorities have signified their willingness to permit the use of the school situated half way between the two reserves.

The Department will approve of the appointment of Mr. Lloyd Gething as teacher and will allow him salary at the rate of $90 per teaching month. You may arrange with him to begin duties as teacher of the summer school at as early a date as possible. Mr. Gething should be informed that he is not to give any religious instruction. It is noted that the regular holidays of the white school are for two months, viz.: July and August, but it will be satisfactory, as far as this Department is concerned, for the temporary Indian summer school to be conducted during September and October, together with Mr. Gething's other pupils, when they return about September first.

Mr. Gething should prepare a return, on the form for that purpose, giving the names of the Indian children only, and forward same at the end of each month, through your office, when a cheque in payment for the salary due will be sent.

Regarding the equipment required, I have to inform you

D.F. H. A. W. Brown,
Indian Agent,
Fort St. John, B. C.
inform you that an order will be forwarded to the Government Stationery Office here to supply the classroom equipment considered necessary for the Indian children during the period the school will be open. The Department is not prepared to furnish certain of the equipment as suggested by Mr. Gething, viz.: teacher's desk and chair, paper towel cabinet with towels, bookcase, desks, etc. However, the Department will approve of the expenditure required in putting up a chimney made of local material, by way of remuneration for the use of the school building. You may also arrange for the purchase and delivery of a lumberman's wood heater. Please obtain an account, in triplicate, which you should attach to proper voucher forms, certify in the usual manner and forward for payment. It is hoped that this summer school will meet with success and that there will be a regular attendance of the Indian children from both reserves.

With reference to the erection of a permanent school building on each reserve at Moberly Lake, with living accommodation for a teacher, I would request that you enquire carefully into the cost of erecting suitable buildings. You might include the cost of building and equipping the schools when forwarding your estimates for the next fiscal year. An effort will be made to provide the amounts required in our Estimates for the fiscal year 1937-38. No doubt, the Indians could do a certain amount of the labour in getting out materials for the buildings. It is considered that it would be more satisfactory to have a school on each reserve than to erect a building half-way between the two reserves.

I shall be pleased to hear from you the date on which Mr. Gething begins teaching activities in conducting the summer school. The Department will endeavour to have the Stationery Department rush the classroom supplies. A flag will be sent from here, also a softball and bat and a football. We do not supply swings or merry-go-rounds.

I shall be pleased if you will give any assistance you can to Mr. Gething in making the summer school a success and in encouraging the Indians to see that their children attend regularly.

Yours truly,

T. R. L. MacInnes,
Acting Secretary.

I beg to submit for your inspection
some correspondence that has taken place between the
Rev. Father E. Allard, O.M.I., of the local R. C.
Mission, and this office.

It will be seen that an effort was made
to induce the Bear Lake Indians who reside over
across the river, and who are part of Father Allard's
community, to leave the Reserve and get out to their
trapping grounds. Father Allard, this Fall, upon

EXTRACT FROM LETTER FROM HARPER REED, INDIAN AGENT,
TELEGRAF CREEK, B. C., dated Sept. 30, 1934,
addressed to Chas. C. Perry, Asst. Indian Commissioner,
Victoria, B. C.

The question of education for the Bear-Lakers, or Klappan Indian children, some families of which number to 13 - 12 - & 9, etc., is yet to be solved. It most certainly requires attention, and the sooner it is taken in hand the better. It hurts your Agent to see all these children growing up without some sort of training.

The Rev. Father E. Allard, O.M.I., is really in charge of their social welfare, at least he maintains he is, but nothing up to now has been accomplished. It is regarded by this office that Father Allard has even more than he can attend to down at McDames Creek, and cannot attend to matters in and around Telegraph Creek.

As is usual, the R.C. Mission has been building all sorts of Mission Houses, and the Church in Dry Town has now an excellent addition joined to the Church itself.

It is thought that, should Father Allard want to give these Bear Lakers social attention, it would be far better for him to go out to their lovely country of the Klappan River - there is no better in the Cassiar, and there start such work as he and the Indian Department think necessary for their betterment.

The whole matter seems part of the old question as to if the Stikine Agency needs an Indian residential school or not, and as you have already gone into the matter most carefully, little need be added now.

Sir:

Sir,

I beg to acknowledge receipt of your very considerate letter, dated November 1st, in regard to a proposed School for the Klappan Indians, known as "Bear-Lakers" that inhabit the district south of Telegraph Creek.

The Rev. Father E. Allard, C.M.I., at present here, has been interviewed several times regarding the subject, and he fully concurs with the view held by this Office, that the correct location for the school should be out in their own country of the Klappan River.

A rather good map has been given the Rev. Father showing the, at present considered, best location - that of the Reserve Lot No. 5972, at Kluachon Lake, which is at the head water drainage of the Isku and Klappan Rivers, and is just 30 miles away from Telegraph Creek. Here exists a natural play-ground for the Indians, containing an abundance of all their requirements, and moreover is actually within their own registered Trapping Grounds.

As the Rev. Father has decided to pass the winter in this upper country, it has been suggested to him, that he runs out to Bulkley Lake, 20 miles distant, and visit the large camp of Indians that are passing the winter at this spot, and go into the matter with them. Your Agent intends to do this, as soon as possible, and it is now expected that the Indians will very readily fall in with the scheme, and offer much help. Father Allard reports that there are in all, 28 youngsters that could attend school, and many more coming along soon.

His Lordship Bishop Bunz is to arrive here about June the 15th next, and the Indians have been instructed to come in for services etc. Then some definite arrangement can be arrived at, but up to then it is almost impossible to do much, but gather information. This of course will be done, and perhaps be so successful that it might be possible for His Lordship to bring along with him the Assistant that will have charge of the proposed school and that such action could be taken right away, during the Bishop's visit.

Where-so-ever the location is to be, a school house will have to be constructed. The matter was mentioned to the Indians last summer, and they stated that it would be nothing to them, to put up a very fine cabin. Perhaps four windows with a couple of doors might be requested, but that would be all they would need. There are at present four new cabins near this spot, which will induce this hand to have their school near-by.

As the whole matter proceeds it shall be reported upon, but it is impossible for Father Allard to take charge of a school, this winter, at the present Indian Camp, for he wishes to remain in town, and give attention to his local residents.

It is desired to submit to the Department, the Agent's many thanks for the valuable assistance that has been afforded his Agency.

Dear Father Allard,

Your note regarding a meeting that has been held in your Mission in regard to the proposed School for the Klappan Band of Indians, has just been received. It is a pleasure for this Office to learn that the matter seems to be now actually under way. It is regretted that I was not present, for there are many matters that must be gone into ere the Indians start to work on the project. Dougan Dennis did call at the Indian Office after your meeting, and agreed that the matter must be gone into slowly, to be permanently good for all concerned.

The first matter of note would be - the location - which Lake have they agreed upon - is it a Reserve - do they know where the lots are - and lastly is it a good - the best location and somewhat "fire-proof".

If it is on the edge of a lake or near by, the cutting of logs etc could be undertaken at anytime, and they could then be floated along the lake. Perhaps a Log School house would be better - cheaper & warmer than a "whip-sawed" cabin or house, especially if it is to be for winter.

Is the School to be run all the Year around, or during the summer - or the winter? The latter idea appeals to most of them as it would free them to continue their Trapping and so produce the necessary revenue - a thing here to do in the summer.

Then who will be their instructor, do you know if your much respected Bishop is willing to bring up some assistant - some person that understands such matters and is willing to go out there and give his careful attention, and advice. This is most important for a village is really being started, and will, I have little doubt, turn out to be a great success, even more so than is possible at Mc Dames Creek Mission.

There is no intention on the part of the Indian Department to stop the Indians coming in to Telegraph Creek for sensible reasons, such as working for an arranged job - selling their furs and obtaining provisions etc- in to see the Doctor etc etc, but the Department will not allow of their coming to town and laying around, with their Girls etc, the way they did last summer, that was a disgrace, and complaints were laid against such conduct by the other Indians of the Tahltan Band. Dougan Dennis agrees to all this, and has so stated.

As previously stated, it would indeed be a very fine act, if you could see your way clear, when the trail are in good shape to go out to the Location and give it your experienced look-over, then we would be assured that they have not too eagerly selected the wrong spot.

You are quite correct in stating that the Department will help this project forward to the best of their ability

I am. Sir, Your obedient servant.

Sir,

I beg to acknowledge receipt of your letter dated December 14th 1934, in regard to the proposed R.C. Mission School for the children of the Klappan Indians, to be, if possible established out in their own country of Klappan.

Submitted are two sets of letter regarding the arrangements as far as they have progressed up to date.

It will be seen that the matter has received a "check" the real reason being yet unknown. It is thought that the Klappan Indians whilst in during the New Year, to bury Norman Dennis an Indian Lad, and also to sell what little fur they had, were influenced by one of their number who is married to a White Man within the Townsite, who is known to rather favour the Klappan Indians being allowed to do what-so-ever they like, when they like.

The Rev Father's letter dated January 12th, was so different from his previous letter dated January 2nd, that he was called upon, and the whole matter talked over.

It was then found that he too seemed to fancy that the school, if established so far away, would be of little service.

Further talk revealed the fact that the new Father was still of the opinion that the Department should establish, or should afford help to do so, an industrial school under the auspices of the supervision of the Roman Catholic Church for all the children under Father Allard's care in this part of the Stikine Agency.

He was carefully questioned as to why the Indians had changed their minds in so short a time, and no reason could be ascertained, except that as the Indians were passing on their way back to their camp at Buckley Lake they stated in a hurry that they did not like the idea.

Father Allard was informed that when it is possible the Indian Agent will go out to their Camp and interview their women, who as yet have not been spoken to; except that last summer when the matter was mentioned everybody agreed with the idea most heartily; and see for himself what is the cause for such a sudden change of front.

Perhaps as the new Father states, nothing much can be done till next spring, as then upon the arrival of His Lordship Bishop Bunoé, all the Indians will be in from far and near, and this event overshadows all else just at present.

However, it is correct to state that your Agent is fully of the opinion that Father Allard intends to make Telegraph Creek the headquarters of the R.C. Mission, and that in every way possible, all effort will be directed towards this end. This Office wishes to thank Your Lordship for the efforts gone to, in bringing this small Band to some idea of unity effort.

Present at the meeting were, Your Lordship, Rev. Father E. Allard, O.M.I., Indian Agent, Chief Charlie Quash of the Thaltans, Douglass Dennis, John Quack, Antwin Tashoots, Frank Tashoots, Jack Tashoots, Baptiste Joseph Dennis, Alex Dennis, Bell Honorat Nole, Nelson Reid. Also were present Larry Martin and David Steack, both of the Thaltan Band, and objected to by the Indian Agent, but allowed to stay during the meeting, by all these present. It was stated later that Scotty Dennis and Guy Reid, of the Klappan Band, desired to attend but could not do so.

A Petition for a School, kind not mentioned—summer or winter to be located near their Church, in Drytown, was first read over by the Indian Agent. The Petition was signed by the following members: Douglass Dennis, John Quack, Alex Dennis, Jack Tashoots, Bell Honorat Nole, F.P. Tashoots, B.J. Mutts Dennis.

The following questions were then asked by the Indian Agent:

Q. Do you want a School? Ans. Yes.

Q. What kind of school do you want? Ans. Here took place some discussion in regard to a Summer School. V. a winter school a little doubt existed, but at last they decided to have a Summer School, during the time they were in Town—summers.

Q. How long do you want the school to be open? Ans. After some talk regarding “seasons—fat meat—etc” they stated— the months of May—June July & August.

Q. Will a Teacher be necessary? Ans. General talk took place and His Lordship decided, and quite correct, that a Teacher was necessary.

Q. What School Building would be used? Ans. It was agreed that the present Church Building would be used—at any rate temporarily. Father Allard thought that the Department should allow some “rent” for its use. This item was promised to be submitted to the Department for their consideration.

Q. What equipment was necessary? Ans. The usual school supplies in fact just the same as for the Mc Dames Mission School. Also it was desired that 24 School Desk-seats should be supplied.

General talk then took place, in which Father Allard thought that a River Scow should be supplied the Mission to assure a steady attendance from across the River, in case the Indians private boats were not in commission.

Having found out more nearly what actually was required, The Indian Agent pointed out the following facts:—

Klappan School Meeting. Contiu. Stikine Agency.

The reasons given in the Petition were not exactly all they seemed to be, in respect for the location.

In regards to a Doctor, the Department could not guarantee his being here all the time. That all Doctors object to continued assistance when the Indians will not carry out instructions. En route to the meeting the Indian agent examined a Teilet, and found same in a disgusting condition. Another family had none.

Regarding Salmon:- It is generally known to be a fact that all the available salmon backwaters are already overfished. To obtain sufficient for their own, and their dogs requirements they would have to move up or down river. Moose are not in the vicinity. Moreover packing moose meat to Town by dogs, means little meat of poor condition. There are no possible gardens here. This all means that "store" provisions must be used, therefore a continuous call for rations. Past events have proven all this.

Town property consists of four unrepairsed, unhealthy houses, generally overcrowded, and upon which Taxes are owing, their owners having to call at the Indian Office for living help.

The promises laid down to keep their families in food whilst in Town has never been kept, and it is difficult to see how they can, and as for moving out to their trapping grounds, at the correct time for their families benefit, to put up "fat" etc and arrange for their seasons trapping, this has always been delayed to the last minute, and results in a large broken down Camp some few miles from Telegraph Creek, from which it is impossible for them to correctly trap their well provided grounds; that being their only revenue. It was shown to be impossible to move a large family, by dogs, to no special spot in the "bush", perhaps 100 miles away - late in the Fall.

And not least, whilst in Town their "girls" were enticed down Town, and bad results come about, as the records show.

Their Agent tried to show them once more that it would be far better to establish a "Klappan Village" out in their own country, and during the long winter days have some good supervision given them, by perhaps their own Authorities. This did not mean that they would not come to Town during the Summer for short times, of necessity they must but it did mean that some sort of Homes would be established, were the Village idea be put into effect.

Map. 38. B. showing all their large trapping Area was shown them. They were also informed that did they not use these grounds, and trap, applications to have them given to other Indians or Whites would be received and would have to have consideration, with this Your Lordship was good enough to concur.

In conclusion, all this matter was promised to be submitted to the Department for their kind consideration, and with the object of having all necessary expenses allowed for in the coming Agency's Estimates, and as instructed by the Department under letter 158-3-1. dated May 8th 1935.

Later, this Band of Indians requested that a Headman be allowed them:- viz Dougeen Dennis, which matter is still receiving the necessary attention of the Indian Office.

All of which, Sir, is an outline of the meeting held as above mentioned.

I am,

Sir,

Your obedient servant.

His Lordship Bishop Bunoz.

The Rev. Father E. Allard, O.M.I.
PRINCE RUPERT, B.C.

Dear Father Allard,

I beg to acknowledge receipt of your letter dated March 7th, which was received a few days ago, upon my return from a visit to Mc Dames Creek. The air-mail will be leaving here in a few days time, and this is the first chance of sending you a reply.

Your letter covers three separate matters, the Mission work at Mc Dames, a proposed school at Liard, and a proposed school for the Klappan Indians within your Church - in Drytown.

Firstly Mc Dames Creek affairs, everything has been settled in regard to the summer's work at this point, everything but the allowance for the Teacher, I believe, and that of course the Department will no doubt fix in due course. Even school supplies have been arranged for and some good few extras have been allowed for in equipment etc. Your school at this point is doing good work, but there is still much to be done in helping the families personally, especially towards a better state of general sanitation. By the end of August the families should be returning to the woods to put up their fat meat, if it is possible to get them to do so. All this really means a full summer's work.

Secondly, Liard affairs. The matter of a school at this point received some little attention, quite awhile ago, and it was understood that the white men with Indian families were behind your efforts, and were intending to put up a school house. Your staking of an "open" piece of ground for this purpose was noticed last summer, but beyond that this Office has little information. However Mr. Anderson writes as follows - "March 21st, Liard, will you please tell Father Allard that I am sawing the lumber for the school and I believe that we can muster up enough energy to stagger through with the job next summer" so it would seem that the matter is already receiving attention, with no doubt the help of the white who have Indian families, a matter that they are quite capable of assisting with, for their fur catches, this winter have been very good indeed. Could you let me know more about this, and then the matter be submitted to the Department for their kind consideration, once more. There has been no request for a teacher's salary for this location submitted as yet, and you know how very difficult it is to have a grant placed at the last minute, all this should have received attention last fall and reported upon.

Thirdly, Telegraph Creek affairs. It is noticed that you desire a small grant to carry on a School within the Church Building, This also should have been submitted to the Department at an earlier date. It is impossible to expect the Department to find these odd amounts, which total seems to amount to around $1000-00, at a moments notice, however the matter shall be submitted, and that, at once.

No mention is made of the proposed Klappan School, which is admitted by everybody, including yourself, to be the very best way of handling the Klappan Indian children who visit this town in the summer time.
No store in the townsite wish to have these Klappan Indians hanging around the district, in fact this office has been requested to "keep them out in the woods." They have little revenue, but have been provided with good trapping grounds, but they will not get out and trap. The stores would put up with them if they were on steady relief, and the department were to pay their accounts, but this the Department, I am very much afraid, will not do. It would be the best way possible of killing them off, and all the help given to their children would be of no avail. This was evident last summer, as we found out. Their girls were around town, and disgusting events took place - too bad to report upon. Also they begat children from the cultus "whites." For example Mary Tashute has now a child by Kennedy, the details of whom you are well acquainted with. It is to stop all this, and obtain a better sanitary condition that the Klappan School was mooted and thought by everybody to be the best move possible.

However, as you state the matter will receive the attention of His Lordship Bishop Bunoa, upon his arrival at this point, but it is certain that the Indians will be "laying" around the reserve, and hanging around the townsite, during the time of His Lordship's visit to the interior, awaiting his passing south again. Other action by this Band can not be expected, unless they are personally conducted out to their chosen location, and a small school mission started at such a point. This office has to hold this viewpoint, it is an Indian office, and exists for the betterment of the Indian with his family. In no way whatever is this viewpoint to be taken as acting adversely in connection with any valuable services given to the children in the District who happen to have white fathers and Indian mothers, possibly 10 or a dozen; it is only expressed on behalf of the Indian whose families have in the past suffered by their summer stay in and around the Town of Telegraph Creek.

Everything will be done that it is possible to do to help forward such a good work, and as stated the Department shall be reported to, upon the matters contained within your letter.

I am,

Sir,

Your obedient servant,

Sir,

Much has been written and many reports submitted on the question of schooling for the Klappan Band of Indians. This Spring and summer the matter has received more attention and is therefore again being reported upon.

The Klappan Band of Indians are nomads and live by trapping in the Klappan River District to the southeast of here about 150 miles. They are all of the R.C. Church, and have very large families. This Band of Indians must not be confused with the Caribou Hide Band, living another 150 miles further south east from this point.

It will be remembered that the late Father E. Allard wished for a Summer School within the Townsite of Telegraph Creek; for this Klappan Band, but it was considered generally that a Winter School in their own district, would result in a far better condition for the Indians, in the long run. With the coming of Father Bosse* O.M.I., now in charge of R.C. Affairs in these parts, the Winter School is the only idea aimed at, and wished for by the Indians and also Father Bosse*.

During the late visit of Inspection by Inspector Pragnell the matter had his very careful attention. Father Bosse was interviewed several times on the matter. Also the Indians concerned with their families were inspected on the Klappan Reserve, by Inspector Pragnell and all wished for the Winter School during the winter of 1936-7. Father Bosse has written His Lordship Bishop Burns, requesting him to find a teacher for his winter school, and Inspector Pragnell has been asked to kindly call upon the Bishop, when passing through Prince Rupert, and come to final arrangements. The Inspector is reporting upon the whole matter.

The site settled upon is the Kleueehoem Reserve, with its good fishing lake nearby. Moose is here in plenty, also good timber. Father Bosse* with your Agent inspected the location and find it a fitting place.

The cost of establishing a community in this location will be a little expensive, mostly owing to pack-horse transportation, the aid of equipment (Windows Doors & Sheet roofing; Heater etc.) with also the extra Salary that should be allowed to any Teacher that will go out there for at least 5 months and take charge of the large Camp. Two important matters will be settled by the establishment of this community:

Firstly schooling for the large families, secondly the settlement of the surviving trappers on individual trapping and Registered rap Grounds. The latter event will produce revenue.

Therefore Sir, it is humbly considered that the matter should now be allowed to go ahead, and a school started this coming Winter.

Attached, and submitted for consideration is an outline of such equipment as will be necessary, with the costs as far as it is at present possible to arrive at.

I am,

The Secretary,
The Dept. Indian Affairs,
OTTAWA.

Your obedient servant,

Harper Need,
Indian Agent.

During the month several small rumors reached the office that matters out at the Klappan Winter school were not going along as smoothly as could be expected, but it was not until that 20th inst. that it was learnt that Father Bosse was trapping instead of supervising the R.C. Mission affairs. Going into the matter it was discovered that the Father has obtained a Trappers License from the local Game Warden to go into partnership with Indian Society Dennis, and trap on his ground. All of which had taken place without notification being allowed the Indian Office. Indian Dennis is a good tempered, well liked nomad, his family consists of 11, including twins - is hopelessly in debt, and of necessity on relief allowances. Last fall he with his wife accepted an offer by this office, whereby he and all his affairs would be carried by the Office- i.e. generally supervised, for the period of two years, when it was considered he would be again, out of debt, and on his own. But with Father Bosse owning 76 traps came along with his offer, it was irresistible, and the office supervision forgotten. This event lead to some little ill feeling amongst the other Indians, and dissatisfaction grew up.

About this time it was also learned that Mr. J. Moran had been teaching the Klappan school. As explained in letter to the Department under date of December 21st, it had been understood that Mr. Moran was only up to help Father Bosse' with the school, the same as happened the previous year when Father Gulette, O.M.I. came up to help the school along. Later Mr. Moran was asked to come in for a chat, which he has done, and it is hoped matters will go ahead now without further hitches. The school attendance is up over that of last winter and Mr. Moran is well liked by the Indian parents and the children. He is quite strict, is certainly a teacher, and is not over bearing on religious routine. It is hoped that the matter of his salary has now been adjusted.

The matter of the local Game Warden granting "whites" permission to trap on Indian Registered Grounds, is of course a difficult matter to handle. It is thought that some arrangement that the Indian Office should be first consulted. The view taken by this office is that such action is fatal, and that eventually the Indians will be roving with the "white" trapper, and so get away and then the white trapper has the line in his own hands, to keep or sell. Indians should take other Indians along if they require help on their lines. Some traplines are so remote that this is necessary. Scotty Dennis was asked why he didn't trap now he has a partner, and he replied that it was no use to do that now -with 76 traps working all the fur would be caught, or enough anyways, and some must be left for next year. It is thought that Father Bosse intends to let Dennis have the traps next year, for his own use.
Up to the end of the month only one good fur catch had been brought in and sold, it consisted of foxes from the Nass Divide. Fur returns are not as good as last year and we are supposed to live over half the year on such revenue.

Dear Sir,

I trust you have read before this my letter to the Superintendent General of Indian Affairs re-Teacher of Klappan school.

Re-Lower Post (or Liard) School.

I wish to say in regard to that school that Mr. H. Reed, Indian Agent at Telegraph Creek, is right when says that a few half-breeds will have to frequent that school. But it is also true to state those half-breed children are real Indians in fact and can be and will be nothing else. Their Fathers themselves live like Indians.

However I'll write again in regard to that matter when I have ascertained what the Provincial Government, for the education of those poor, isolated half-breeds.

Re-Moricetown School

Although I have no official notice that this school has been granted, I am told that it has been. Hence I have had some correspondence with Mr. McKay, Commissioner at Vancouver in connection with the appointment of a teacher. But so far no substantial headway has been made in the matter. Some confusion has arisen from the fact the first teacher appointed resigned in favor of her Brother who was refused, it seems by Capt. Barry. On hearing that her Brother could not succeed her, the girl appointed, Miss Bernice Sargent, now insists in holding the position herself. And that so far as we are concerned in that affair, I hope that some satisfactory solution will be found soon.

KLAPPAN WINTER DAY SCHOOL

The location of this school is out in Klappan District, south of telegraph Creek. It serves a whole lot of nomads and acts as a concentration camp for the very large families during the winters, when the head of the family has to travel long distances for trapping purposes. The school ran all last winter in one or two very good cabins erected for this purpose - it is on a reserve nearby a Lake. The school was successful from its start, and good progress was made by the children. The R.C. Missions of these parts have again requested this Office to place before The Department for their kind consideration, the matter of the rate of Pay allowed the R.C. Mission teachers.

The various missions are as follows:
- Klappan Day School. 60 miles out in the bush. South Dease Lake School. (starting 1937) 73 miles from Telegraph Creek.

It has been suggested that owing to remote places and expensive transportation - high cost of food - and only a short season, that a little more pay should be considered in accordance with the distance the school is away from the Head of Navigation - i.e. Telegraph Creek.

Your Agent here cannot but sympathize with their views on the matter, especially as it costs at least $50-00 to come up, and return to Wrangell from where the C.P.S/ship is left. The Cassiar is much more difficult, and expensive to get into and live than is the Yukon, so the actual savings of a Teacher can be but very little.

- Klappan Day School @ $100-00 per month.
- Dease Lake Day School $100-00
- Mc Dames Creek -- $110-00
- Liard Post Day School (if allowed) $115-00 per month

I beg to submit herewith the KLAPPAN DAY SCHOOL Reports for the months of November and December 1936.

It will be seen that the attendance is not quite up to expectations, which has come about through no real intentions of the Indians concerned. Three more large families should have been located at this school, by now but owing to no snow at all in places on this Klappan Trail, the families could not move. Moreover this fall two big game parties stayed on and hunted in the first light fall of snow, and this held the families of the Guides here. The Indians who did not get their families there, are remorseful, and intend next year to be there—on time.

This band comes from the south and east of Telegraph Creek, in a very wild country, with access by trail only, about 60 miles from Telegraph Creek. As already reported, I saw most of this band camped on the opposite side of the river at Telegraph Creek. There are swarms of children, all uneducated. In this case an attempt is being made by the Indian Agent, in conjunction with the R.C.Missionary to establish a winter school. The elder Indians are very keen that their children should learn something, and have promised to leave their wives and children at some suitable and selected spot, prepare firewood, deer flesh and kill game and fish food. If necessary they will leave a hunter to kill game. They will also erect log shelter and the sides of a school room, while we could fit tent top over this and put in a heater; also quarters for a teacher. Much expenditure would not be required to start off with, as it would be in the nature of an experiment. I hope that it will meet with success. Considerable organizing will be required of Mr. Reed. I understand that Bishop Bunoz would arrange for a teacher.

Health:

In general it might be said that the health of the children is extremely good. The outdoor environment in which they are associated has no doubt played an important part in maintaining their healthy conditions which, apart from such minor troubles as colds and inflamed eyes, has not been attacked by any disease of a serious nature.

Two rather advanced cases of trachoma exist among adult members of the encampment but do yet have not spread to the eyes of the children. Steps are being taken to combat any infection and it is to be hoped that the cooperation of the present victims can be had.

I might state here that the treatment of trachoma is not a new undertaking with me. Having acted in the capacity of disciplinarian at the Tyee Residential School for 5½ years, I have had the pleasure of meeting Mr. Hall and witnessing...
many of his operations and treatment
cases as well as receiving several
lectures on how to care for and assist in
the prevention of Trachoma. The treatment
advised by Dr. Hall to the several boys
under my care was each day personally
supervised by me.

The eyes, however, seem to be a weak
factor among the children of this
school and an inflammation of the eyes
has kept a number of the children from
attending classes for some time. That
has the appearance of a cataract has
been forming on the eye of one youngster
and caused her to miss the entire
autumn term of school. Another child
shows a decided weakness of the eyes
with a slight turning of one. The parents
of both children have been advised to
have the youngsters examined by a
doctor at the first opportunity.

Among the older members of the
camp there is one very evident case of
cataract which has been brought to the
attention of the Indian Agent who, I am
sure, will do all in his power to have
this sad malady remedied.

Classroom:

I do not consider it will be necessary
for me to go over in detail the progress
made in the school since its inauguration
in October 1936; but let it suffice for me
to remark upon conditions since I took
over the teaching position just four
months previous.

The pupils here show a decided aptitude
to study with a firm desire to attend
daily class. Progress is rapid and
an anxiousness for advancement is
quite noticeable. Attention in class is keen and any new place in the work is eagerly anticipated.

The monthly report forwarded to your office shows the splendid attendance of the children and for this I must congratulate the parents for the cooperation they have given in seeing that no child is detained at home unnecessarily.

General Remarks:

Taking advantage of a short interim in which I was relieved of classroom duties by Father Ross, I took the opportunity of visiting Telegraph Creek and interviewing the Indian Agent at that point regarding some of the conditions existing in that Lake.

It was a rather pleasant surprise to Mr. Reid (IA) to learn that the school now boasts an enrollment of 81 pupils with an expected increase of from 3 to 5 more for next year. Such a number in excess of last year's attendance makes the seating capacity of the present building inadequate.

At the time of construction things were rather of an undecided nature and work had to be rushed. It was expected that at the most the enrollment would not exceed 15 pupils and in consequence a building was erected to accommodate that number with teacher's quarters in the rear. Today the entire unit would not be too spacious.

The school is situated some 65 miles from Telegraph Creek from which point supplies have to be brought in via horse train in summer and dog team in winter making the cost of feeding excessive and at times inconvenient. Because of the high rates prevailing one has to deprive himself of many necessities which, to the good of one's health, should be on hand.
The wood supply is an item of much concern. It is procured from a distance of about 1/2 mile and the trees have to be felled, sawed into lengths and hauled to the schoolhouse where they are sawn into stove lengths. All this is done by the school staff without any assistance from the native settlers.

The amount of fuel required can only be realized by one who has encountered a northern British Columbia winter and suffered the draughts of a log building constructed more for educational purposes than for protecting the teacher and children from wintry blasts.

At one time the building was covered with moss but this material has since dried out and though repeated requests have been made to have the school re-roofed no effort has been made to do the work. To this end I cannot give commendation to the Indians for the support they have given in maintaining the school.

As much as the school was opened for their convenience and good of their children I do believe that some means should be taken to make them support the school at least with a little labor for which they have plenty of time.

In closing, I wish to express my gratitude to Mr. Reed for his kindly interest he has shown me in my "habitation" and pioneer existence and also offer my thanks for his assistance and timely advice so kindly proffered.

Respectfully Submitted,

J.E. Moran
Teacher Flappan Indian School

Dear Sir,

I beg to submit a report of my visit to, and inspection of; The Klappan Winter School, situated about 60 miles to the south east of this Town. The reason for such visit was a letter received from Indian Guy Reid that his wife was seriously ill, after a confinement, and expected to die - and also a letter from the School master informing me that the Chicken Pox Epidemic had reached that remote area, and several cases needed a Doctor's attention.

Therefore on the morning of January 16th a start was made by J. C. Dennis's team of 6 dogs, which allowed of my arrival at the School Area at 5 P.M. on the 17th inst.

The indian woman was at once seen, and found to be in a very weak condition, due to loss of blood. This received immediate attention and by the next morning all hemorrhaging bleeding had ceased, and the woman was on a fair way to recovery. It was found that the Chicken Pox epidemic had nearly gone its course with the children of this community and there were no fresh cases. Attention was given this matter and further need for worry need not be given this outbreak.

With regard to the general health of this camp, this was found to be good as a whole. Situated here were fourteen families - 29 Adults and 42 children. It was found that 21 children were in attendance at school. Upon inspection of these children, several were found suffering from enlarged tonsils and adenoids, with two cases of septic tonsillitis. It is considered that these latter cases should receive attention during the summer months, when they come in to Town. Several cases of Myopia were discovered, these should be supplied with glasses, so that their efforts at the school might be brought to full benefit. Indian Dougan Dennis whose eyes received attention in Vancouver last summer, was now found to be totally blind. This man requested an advance in the issue of his relief, as he is now helpless to fend for himself. I wish to report that there were two cases of bone tuberculosis, both of which were in the hands, and one of which the finger should be removed. One Girl age 16 showed signs of T.B. Pulmonary, and this case will receive further attention when she arrives in town next Spring.

In regard to vaccination, it was found that 10 youngsters had not been vaccinated at all, and five others were found upon whom the last vaccination had not "taken." This summer it is my intention to look over all the Indians and give attention where due.

At the Indian Agent's request an inspection of the School itself was undertaken, and the following data is rendered.
Dr. G.W. Meyer's Inspection Report—contiu.

Mr. J.A. Moran the Schoolteacher, was found to be doing splendid work. As stated there were 21 children in attendance, they were well disciplined and their ability to sing a number of well selected songs was quite a revelation. The children were well dressed and neat appearing to enjoy their training. Also the parents were well satisfied with the progress made, and spoke highly of Mr. Moran's ability as a teacher.

The school building consists of a log house 30 x 19 which has been divided by a partition into school room and a small living quarters for the Teacher. Father Bosse O.M.I. has built a lean-to at one end of the building, which it is stated was at his own expense, and when visiting the community holds his services within this school-house. Mr. Moran assured me that he allows no interference with the regular school hours by the Church.

The flooring of this school is extremely rough, and difficult to keep clean, but Mr. Moran is endeavoring to persuade the Indians to whip-saw enough lumber for a better floor, which they can do with the equipment supplied last Fall. The lighting of this building is not what it should be. There are only two long narrow windows supplying the daylight. Whilst these windows are in the right position, being behind and to the right of the children, there should be another window on their left side. This Mr. Moran intends to correct in the near future.

In conclusion it is mentioned that I consider this a very happy venture; the parents seemed most satisfied and there is no doubt but that the children are receiving much benefit from their school attendance.

Yours truly,

[Signature]

Dr. G. W. Meyer, M.D.

Dear Sir:

At request of Indian Office I made a trip to Klappan Day School, situated on Iskut Lake, 60 miles south-east of Telegraph Creek, at which J. E. Moran is teacher.

On January 2nd some Indians, parents of children attending Klappan School, had reported at Indian office that a good deal of sickness prevailed at the camp, chiefly sore throats, and that a woman expecting a child was suffering from a heart ailment, and expected trouble at her approaching confinement.

We left Telegraph Creek on the 5th inst., the Indian Office providing dog team and driver, headed for the Klappan School area. This year the trail was very difficult, owing to scarcity of snow, especially over the Lava Beds, and progress was slow on account of open water due to mild weather and necessitating a relay over the Goat Mountain as the South Fork of the Stikine was wide open. However, Klappan was reached on the evening of Jan. 8th. A runner from Klappan met us on the trail 20 miles out and reported that the childbed case was in serious condition and had been in labor for two days without being able to effect delivery. I therefore decided to continue the trip after dark, and we arrived in the camp long after nightfall. Here immediate attention was given to the woman in trouble, which was found to be a case of mal-presentation, impossible of delivery without aid, by their own efforts. By midnight the child was delivered, and both mother and child left in good condition.

On the following morning a medical inspection was made of the camp and several cases of adenitis and sore throats attended to. It is considered that the recent epidemic of septic sore throat which had swept over Telegraph Creek and vicinity had about exhausted itself, leaving behind as after-effects quite a few cases of adenitis, all of which are receiving treatment.

At Klappan I found the following families in residence:

(1) Antoine Tashoots, wife, and two children;
(2) Maggie Pete, living with Tashoots family, and two children;
(3) Frank Pete, wife, and one child;
(4) John Quok, wife, and eight children, including Julia baby;
(5) Alec Dennis, wife, and three children;
(6) Joe Mutz, wife and four children;
Mr. Harper Reed, page #2

Jan. 12, 1940.

(7) Doggan Dennis and wife;
(8) Bell Nole, wife and three children.

There were two cases of trachoma, Jos. Nats and Mrs. John Quok, both of which received treatment.

1. Case of suspected T.B. A boy 17 years old whose sister died nine months ago of pulmonary T.B. This case was instructed as to isolation and care of his sputum.

2. Case of acute tonsilitis.

3. Cases of adenitis with discharging glands.

All of which were given appropriate treatment.

At the request of the Indian Agent, affairs of the school were enquired into, and the teacher was asked why no reports had been rendered. Mr. Moran explained that he was not responsible to the Indian Office and took all his instructions from the Bishop, and that it was not his duty to report births and deaths to the Indian Office. After discussing the matter with him, he agreed to do so in the future, and gave me a report to hand to the Indian Agent at Telegraph Creek, notifying him of two births. He also stated that in October there were no Indians here and hence school had not been held. In November there was too much sickness, such as septic sore throats, and there were only two school children, which increased to 9 children by November 15th, but these were ill. Therefore school opened on December 1st with an attendance of eleven (11) children, and this was the number of children in attendance on my visit.

As my visit fell due on Saturday and Sunday, I did not see any children at the school. He expected a better attendance shortly as several families were moving in, and were now on their way. The school building seemed to be in fair shape, but required some roofing material to stop leaks caused by holes in the roofing material. Mr. Moran also asked me to request permission from you to be allowed to close school early in April, which would enable him to bring in his supplies before the winter trails broke up.

After completing inspection and giving all medical aid, as far as possible, we commenced our return trip to Telegraph Creek, visiting en route all Indians' camps, including Guy Reid and family, Scotty Dennis and family, Nelson Reid and Isabel Reid, and reached Telegraph Creek on the evening of January 10th.

Re:- Klappan Day School - Winter.

I beg to submit herewith, a Day School Report, covering the month of December 1939 for the above school. This Report was brought in by Mr. Meyer, upon his return from a medical inspection for the school area, and is the first information of the schools affairs received this winter. Mr. Moran visited Telegraph Creek a day or so during the first of the Year, but did not call at this Office. A call would have been paid him, had it not been stated by one of the Klappan Indians, that Mr. Moran would call later on; but he returned to Klappan without my seeing him.

Teacher Moran's remarks on this Report call for some explanation and they are as follows:

In regard to the month of October, Mr. Moran was in this Office on the 9th of that month and signed his Teachers Papers, and we were both well aware of the fact that the Indian families were late in moving out to their winter Quarters. There was some delay again this year on the arrival of the school supplies, but with a few extra school supplies purchased from the H.B. Coy., sufficient was supplied to carry the school along. These went out by pack train on the 16th of that month.

The real fault with this fall down of attendance can be laid to the fact that all the Indians of this district made very good wages over the summer months, and at the end of the season, delayed their movement out to the woods for the enjoyment of Town life as long as possible. Then as it happened an epidemic of Septic Sore Throats attacked through this district, and caused a further delay, so that no doubt such sickness hindered the opening-up of this school.

Dr. Meyer, who has just returned from an inspection of that point, reports that the epidemic has worn itself out and that the month of January should see a better attendance. Mr. Moran questioned the Doctor as to if the Department would allow his salary over that time it was impossible to operate the school; but that, as the Doctor stated was a matter entirely for the Department to decide upon.

Also a request was received from Teacher Moran, that he be allowed to close up this school earlier this year than usual. It seems he wished to come into Town to freight out some supplies of what kind is not known, but in time to do so are the winter trail thaws out. All the school supplies forwarded for the use of this school are already out there, and there are no more departmental supplies to be forwarded until next summer. It is considered that as the school started so late, that the school term should be continued as long as possible, this year.

It is my duty to report that for the last two seasons, matters generally have not been going along as smoothly as could be wished for in connection with this Winter School's Affairs. The reason for this is unknown, and the Parents of the children attending the school upon being questioned, avoid a direct reply.
It is thought however that perhaps some little extra attention is allowed some families, whilst others think perhaps they are being slighted, but whatever it is, Indian style, no information can be obtained to go upon.

Teacher Moran has done excellent work at this point, for which we are very thankful, and he is an excellent Teacher, but if it were possible to have an exchange of Teachers, if only for one season; it is considered it would improve the situation to some extent.

This winter bush school was started as an experiment, with the object in view of giving training to these nomadic children, and at the same time allowing their fathers to continue their trapping with less family troubles to look after. At the start it was very successful, and everybody was delighted. The fur returns showed some improvement. This carried along until Father Joseph paid more attention to trapping affairs than to the conduct of the school, and the necessary family affairs that always claim consideration in such a camp; and to speak truthfully we have not yet recovered from the unsettled state of affairs that then came about.

However, it is hoped that this Agency may be granted a visit by the Inspector of Indian Agencies for B.C., this coming summer, and then it will be possible for him to interview some of the parents and find out exactly what steps to take, for the continuation of a very useful, and much wanted winter school.

Under separate cover is submitted Dr Meyer's Report upon his visit to this point, in which it will be seen that he arrived just in time to save the life of an Indian woman, who was in child-birth trouble. Also he mentions one or two items that are required at this school, all of which will receive due attention ere the next school season opens up.

I am,

Sir,

Your obedient servant,

Dear Major MacKay:

With reference to part of the monthly reports from Mr. Indian Agent Reed, particularly that dated January 1940 and attached extracts handed to me by Inspector Coleman, I may say that the matter of the continuation of part time and summer schools in the northern part of the Province was discussed with His Excellency Bishop Bunoz, O.M.I., yesterday.

I pointed out to His Excellency that Mr. Reed's reports in connection with Mr. Moran's work appeared to be far from satisfactory. It should be noted that Mr. Moran is not a Catholic Priest. His Excellency did not of course support Mr. Moran in the foolish idea that this man's responsibility was to him alone and agreed with me that all necessary reports and returns called for by the Department should be submitted to the Indian Agent.

I suggested to His Excellency that the Department might not have sufficient funds to carry on Summer and part time schools in the northern part of the Province this year, and was informed that so far no official letter had been received by the Bishop to this effect. His Excellency is anxious to know at once what can be done as the teachers in some cases come to British Columbia from a distance for this summer work, students from Edmonton, etc. His Excellency also pointed out that if the Department had decided to discontinue these schools the question of the dismissal of Mr. Moran would solve itself.

May I suggest that this letter be forwarded with your recommendations to Mr. Hoey, and that the Department be asked to write as soon as possible to His Excellency Bishop Bunoz, O.M.I., to inform him that along with the part time and summer schools of other denominations the grants made to Catholic Summer schools and other part time schools will be discontinued for the duration of the war.

I explained to Bishop Bunoz that the Department had not sufficient funds to carry on the whole of the educational work previously attempted in British Columbia, that the Catholic Church was not being particularly picked out for a reduction of grants, and that we were making an effort to so reduce expenditures where this could be done that the regular Indian schools might be carried on. Bishop Bunoz was informed of my recommendation that in several non-Catholic schools I had recommended a reduction from a ten month academic year to one of nine or eight months. Bishop Bunoz was assured that the United Church and Anglican schools were being dealt with in exactly the same way as the Catholic schools.

The Bishop did not raise any objection to the closing of these part time schools under the present circumstances, but wished to be informed of the Department's decision as soon as possible.

Three such Indians as mentioned above, came in from the Caribou Hide District—200 miles away—and meeting Father Carpentier at the Klappan School location, en route in, mentioned that as a school had not opened up out at their Camp, they were seriously considering coming in to the Klappan School; so that their children might attend that school. Sir:

I am today in receipt of a communication from His Excellency Bishop Buno where he quotes certain charges against me that have gone forward to you from Mr. Reed the local Indian Agent.

If you will allow me I shall refute each and every statement made therein.

Firstly, Mr. Reed states that I keep dogs and spend most of my time at White Passer Bill Elder's. The former is correct; but these are sleigh dogs, the necessity of which can only be realized by one who has spent much time in the bush. I am located 70 miles from Telegraph Creek and all winter freighting and packing are by means of dogs. The keeping of these animals do not disrupt my school.
Hours in the least as I procure their feed on Saturdays. If keeping them is contrary to any rule of the department—I was never made aware of it—and had I been such never would have happened.

At times mine were the only dogs in camp and on one occasion when having to send for the doctor I was glad to have had them.

As to the latter portion of Mr. Reed's statement I can only say the derivation of his information is unfounded. Mr. Elder is the only white neighbor between me and Telegraph Creek and is located some 15 miles west. I visited him four times all winter going over on Friday evening and returning on Saturday evening sometimes on Sunday.

Secondly, I am accused of being unco-operative. To refute this I think it will suffice to relate a recent incident.

Mr. Reed requested me this spring to have the Indians sign a paper relative to their school. Immediately set about having
the matter attended to and in due course forwarded home the paper duly signed. However, it appeared that what I had sent was not precisely what he desired. Two weeks after the school closed Mr. Reed wrote me requesting that I have another sheet drawn up. At the time I had left Klappan and the letter reached me a month later in Telegraph Creek. All mail between Telegraph and Klappan is by courier on occasion.

If I were failing in my duties of co-operation do you think Mr. Reed would make requests of me after my work as teacher was at an end?

Mr. Hoey, I am constantly anxious to be co-operative with Mr. Reed but the matter in question must not involve anything personal and not relative to the school.

Thirdly I am of the habit of visiting Telegraph Creek and fail to call on the agent.

Sir, I am located 70 miles from the agent's office and Telegraph
Week and therefore it would hardly appear that I could make a habit of visiting Telegraph.

I was in town at New Year's and again at Easter for supplies and on both occasions called on the Agent. On the latter I bought supplies to the end of May which I presumed to be the end of the school year. I got report forms from Mr. Reed and he never as much as informed me that the school would close March 31st. On my return to Klapapan I received the letter of information which had gone through to another Indian village by the courier. Mr. Reed gave me the report forms.

In justice to Mr. Reed I wish to state that the closing of the school was a mis-understanding of a request I had made to him in January.

Each time I am in from the school I call on Mr. Reed that any business can be talked over while before leaving for Klapapan each fall I call on him beforehand.
The only occasion on which I was called to conduct business was in connection with the last request from Mr. Reed, aforementioned. This letter was brought to me by the Indians just as I was preparing to leave for the interior. Mr. Reed, so I was told, had left that same morning for Attlin. Under the circumstances I used the local mail.

Fourthly, it is stated that I refuse vital statistics. On my files at the Klappan School at the present time I have Mr. Reed's acknowledgements of the vital statistics reported by me. My reports relate to births and deaths there not having been any marriages. Are there other vital matters that I have failed to report? If so, it is because I have been kept ignorant of their nature.

Fifthly—I claim to be responsible to the bishop alone. Nothing could be further from the truth. This statement can only date back to a more or less personal matter which I do not deem necessary to mention here. I am fully aware...
Of my responsibilities to the Indian Department.

Mr. Reed's sixth accusation is in connection with one Mac Stephens, whom it is said I have encouraged to trap on Indian trap lines. Mr. Hoey, believe me when I say, Mac Stephens has not been with me for two years except on occasion to visit which lasts two days at the most. I think, if my memory serves me correctly, I saw him three times all last winter. He is located 35 miles from me down the Skeine River with another white man.

By corresponding with the local game department you will learn the gentleman in question had not even a trapper's license.

Three years ago an Indian offered him the right to trap and I advised against it as no one knows better than I what trouble arises therefrom.

You may wonder why such accusations should be made.
Sir Mr. Reed if they are not true. For myself I know him and my own opinion is that he never expected me to be confronted with the statements. Personal matters and business should, in my sense of reckoning, be separated but under the conditions I think I am justified in saying that our first fall-out was due to lie in which Mr. Reed's own letter will act as his accuser. I have it on file also.

If my services, Mr. Hoey, are not satisfactory I am willing to relinquish my position. The Indians, as can be attested to by a petition forwarded to Bishop Buno, are pleased with my work while a glimpse over my requisition for supplies will show you my time is not wasted.

I thank you kindly for your attention and realizing your position I know I can rely on you for justice in this case.

Very truly yours,

J.E. Moran

I beg to submit herewith a letter received from His Lordship Bishop Bunoz, O.M.I., of Prince Rupert B.C., regarding Mr Moran, who has in past times acted as Teacher for this school. Also attached is the Indian Office acknowledgement to the above letter.

Both the Doctor, and your Agent consider that a Reverent Father should be placed in charge of this winter Camp, for at least one season. The late unsettled conditions caused by Rev. Father Bosse O.M.I., has not yet passed away, and today this camp is looked upon, as a "place to stop" by all the half-breeds that travel out that way and some that go there, specially. This unruly state of affairs would no doubt cease were a Father placed in charge.

As the Department will understand, it is not necessary to have a "straight" Teacher in charge, these nomadic youngsters will learn almost as much from a Father as they would otherwise. Some of the older Indians concerned have been discreetly questioned on this matter, and they certainly would like to have a Father in charge, over the winter months.

No doubt but what Mr Moran is a very good teacher, but a "hurry-up" and "get-away from the camp" routine has come about, and so the Indians, mostly the women consider that the Mission is not thinking very much of their welfare. Moreover Mr Moran has taken up mining during the summer time, which is excellent of course, and it is thought that perhaps he would prefer to carry on such interests, the whole year around.

All preparations have been made for the opening up of this school, next winter, and the school supplies will go out at the first opportunity, after the arrival at this point.

The enclosed account has been handed to this office by Rev. Father Arsenault, teacher of the Klappan Seasonal School. It was the first intimation this office received that the R.C. Church expected this Department to bear the cost of putting in a new floor and toilet at the Klappan School. The teacher had no more than casually mentioned that he had two Indians working for him at the school.

The account is somewhat misleading in that it shows both Jack and Frank Tashoots as having cut 530 feet of lumber at 35¢ a foot. Actually only 530 board feet was cut; the Church paid the men the very high price of $700.00 per thousand board feet for the lumber. Although it had to be logged and whip-sawn by hand the price of $371.00 for 530 f.m. is still very high. Milled lumber could be purchased in town and hauled out to Iskut Lakes Camp by dog-sled (60 miles) for not more than $250.00.

The school building had a very rough floor in it with wide cracks between the boards which made the school room drafty in cold weather. The school certainly needed a new floor and a new toilet, and if the cost had been reasonable the work would be justified under ordinary conditions. Unfortunately an unforeseen circumstance arose which prevented the operation of the school this season; the majority of the Indians who usually camp at Iskut Lakes remained at Buckley Lake on account of the mild weather and difficulty of transporting their families over bare ground and open rivers. They were also undoubtedly influenced in staying nearer town by the demoralizing epidemics they went through last winter without any medical assistance. These people will probably return to the Iskut Lakes Camp next winter but of course there is no assurance they will do so. The Camp is central to most of the Indians' traplines, the wood supply is good and fish and game are not too hard to procure from the Camp.

The school building was constructed by the R.C. Church with about $300.00 assistance from the Department in 1937.

The alternative to this suggestion would be to endeavour to purchase the Missions' share in the schools but I would definitely not recommend this course as I believe that it would be far less expensive, even over a period of years, to pay an annual rental of $75.00 in the case of the Dease Lake and Klappan schools and possibly Lower Post or McDame Creek if either operates, than to purchase these crude log buildings and try to improve them. From past experience it seems that the operation of these bush schools is quite provisional, depending as it does upon whether or not the Indians camp at the location of the school during the usual term. At the present time it seems that any extensive outlay for establishing day school buildings would be unwise, especially in the more remote locations because it is evident that the Indians in this area as a whole are still not inclined to settle permanently in one location. Their houses in and near Telegraph Creek for the most part are used only as stopping over places between their trapping and fishing camps. This has been more evident during the past fall and winter when these people have had to earn their living from the country, as they did prior to the freighting boom from 1941 to 1943 when supplies were going in by this route to Watson Lake Airport. It seems that the life-long habits of the Indians will not easily be changed, even to ensure the education of their children and the more or less temporary bush schools will probably have to serve, at least for the present.

The teachers of the seasonal schools in this agency have complained from time to time of the delay in receiving their salary cheques. For instance, recently Father Carpentier, O.M.I., who taught at Klappan School from March 26 to the end of April, 1945, advised that he has not yet been paid for his services. In this particular case it was no doubt Father Carpentier's delinquency in submitting the required tax exemption forms which held up payment, but there is usually a delay of a month or two after the conclusion of a quarter, before the salary is received.

The teachers state that this delay causes them some embarrassment when prompt settlement of their accounts is expected by stores. It often means that a store is obliged to wait several months for payment of an account. The teacher of Klappan School must take his supplies out in December, or even earlier, and yet it is perhaps the middle of May before he receives a cheque for the quarter ending March 31. In the first place there is frequently delay in getting the quarterly returns in to this office owing to difficulties of transportation. Then there is the usual tie-up in the mail service during the spring break-up, which may cause a further delay of two months or more.

Would it be possible for an advance to be deposited with this office, and payment of salary made at the end of each quarter, or monthly if the latter could be approved?

Dear Bishop Coudert;

I am writing this letter from Carcross on my way to Atlin.

In discussing the charter trip made by Father Forget to Iskut Lake I learned from the Northern Airways that Father Forget had notified the pilot, Pat Callison, that the Indian Affairs Branch was paying 2/3 of the cost. I do not know what Father Forget would tell the pilot that for, because as you know my offer was to pay 1/3 the cost. My offer was based upon the weight of our respective loads.

The load which this department had originally arranged to send out was:

- Nurse Dunn 150
- Medical supplies 50
- School Books & tools... 50
- Rations for Indi. 150
- Total: 400

but I am informed that we didn't actually have that much weight. The total load taken by Mr. Callison was 1200 lbs., which means that out of that total probably 850 lbs. was Father Forget's load. Under the circumstances, and considering too that Father Forget had previously obstinately refused to take up my offer of 1/3 cost, and stated he was chartering the plane himself and didn't wish the assistance of my office, I certainly cannot consider asking the Department to pay for 2/3 of the cost.

I also learn from the Northern Airways that the cost of the charter will be about $225.00, as it took them 2 1/4 hours flying to get in to the lake. Bad weather made them turn back on their first attempt after they had got within about ten miles of their destination. Then on the final return trip to Telegraph Creek they found the area around the town fogged in and had to return to Buckley Lake for two hours to wait until it cleared. Personally I do not think that the Northern Airways Company should expect you to pay for all that flying time when the complete trip under normal conditions would have taken 1 1/2 hours at the very most. I would therefore suggest that you take this up with Mr. George Simmons when he returns.

When you arrived at an understanding with Mr. Simmons I would suggest that you bill this office for a third of the cost arrived at and I will submit the account to the Department for payment.

Re: Airplane Charter to bring School Teacher and other supplies to Klappan

Dear Sir:

Your recent communication dated January 23 came to me as a shock. No one is to be blamed but you and I concerning the arrangements made by Father Forget with pilot Pat Callison for the trip to Klappan. When you visited me recently on your return trip from Lower Post and discussed this matter with me, I clearly pointed out to you that I was not prepared to pay a charter to Klappan and that I considered it to be the duty of the branch to arrange for the transportation of the teacher and school supplies, as well as other Indian supplies to such an out-of-the-way place.

I told you of the difficulties we had in the past with your predecessor over a similar matter concerning the season's school at Cariboo Hide, after our school teacher Jim Anolin, and later on Father Plaine nearly lost their lives trying to reach Cariboo Hide over land with all their supplies, and actually spent more money for the trip and back than they actually received from the branch for their work as teachers, besides having to live most of the time during the school term on an Indian fare of dried straight moose meat and fish. Following such hardships, and owing to the lack of adequate cooperation from the branch, I then decided to close the School at Cariboo Hide, though we had at that point the most interesting band of Indian children anxious to receive some education.

A somewhat similar situation exists at Klappan; about every year the missionary teaching at Klappan has to risk his life to reach the place overland, breaking through the ice or falling in the rivers to be drowned; on the only occasion I had to make the trip overland to Klappan two years ago, I myself met with a serious accident and came back crippled to Telegraph Creek. On the other hand the hiring of horses or dog sleds with experienced drivers has proved as expensive as the charter of a plane and far less satisfactory for the time and difficulties involved.

On Dec. 7th last, I wrote to the Superintendent of our Indian Affairs in Ottawa, protesting against such a state of affairs and asking him to take this matter up with the Officials of the Branch so that clear instructions be given to you from Ottawa regarding the expenses of trans-
