Dear Sir;

Some time ago I brought to the attention of the Officials of the Branch,through Father O.Plourde,the necessity for the Branch of doing something about the transportation of the School Teacher to such an out of the way place as Klappan School.

Notwithstanding the efforts of Father Forget,the school teacher,to work out some satisfactory arrangement with Agent Sampson for a chartered flight to Klappan,no solution had yet been found until the Indian Agent came and visited me in Whitehorse in January.

Having to send some medical supplies,school supplies,relief rations and the district Nurse to Klappan,the Indian Agent finally agreed to work out a commun charter with our school teacher;I clearly understood from him that we could have the charter charged to his office,provided father Forget would pay one third of the total cost of said charter to him.

I really thought that we were doing more than our share in consenting to this agreement,since father Forget would make use of the plane only for his way out,whilst the nurse visiting the Indians would make the total round trip;he would be sharing the plane with the nurse and the other indian supplies,whilst on the return trip the plane would be entirely at the disposal of the Indian Agent both for the nurse and for some possible eventual patient to be brought in.-I immediately wired father Forget ,at my own expense to get ready ,as soon as possible,and leave for Klappan,as he was already two weeks late for lack of transportation;I mentionned in my night letter the conditions of the agreement passed with the Agent,as you may see in the enclosed correspondance.

Much to my surprise I received a few days later the enclosed letter from Agent Sampson;you will also find attached my answer and father Forget own version of the story.

All expected the charter to amount to some $150.00 at most;now the Northern Airways is asking $225.00.-Moreover,Agent Sampson insist that we pay 2/3 of said charter,viz.$150.00.-Imagine a teacher going to teach for four months in an out of the way place having to pay $150.00 for his one way trip only..Father Forget has already paid $43.00 on said charter,and I am willing to let him pay the full third promised on the actual cost of the charter,but no more.

I wish you would instruct Agent Sampson to be reasonable;we are willing to pay him what is just on that charter but no more.

Dear Sir;

Referring to my letter of Dec. 18, 1946, whereby I notified Your Department that Father Jh. Forget would be available to teach in October, November and December at Shesley, B.C., in the Stikine River Agency, I now find it impossible to send Father Jh. Forget to teach at that point, at such a time. I beg, therefore, to submit for your approval the name of Father M. Turcotte O.M.I., who had some experience already last winter when he conducted the school at Klappan.

If the attendance proves to be satisfactory, Father Turcotte may continue on the school for a longer period of time after Christmas. I will, in this case, suggest Father Jh. Forget's name as the school teacher in Klappan, as soon as weather conditions allow the Indians to gather at that point.

In order to make the conduct of these two schools possible, in this particularly difficult district, I was obliged to send a third missionary, at least for the winter months, so that our missionary work elsewhere in the district would not be neglected, such as in Cariboo Hide, Dease Lake, and Telegraph Creek.

I am sure that Your Department will appreciate the tremendous sacrifices we are making for the educational benefit of the Indians located in that area, and will, therefore, give us directly or through your local Agent, all the encouragement our missionaries stand very much in need of. I was placed between the alternative of closing completely this field or sending some reinforcement to our missionaries.

Dear Mr. Neary;

I have your letter File 158-7-1(E.1) regarding the schools to be conducted by Father Ed. Turenne. I also received your cheque of $456.00 for his work at the Lower Post Seasonal Schools in June, July and August of this year.

1.-Regarding his school reports concerning his work at Lower Post, I understand that he sent the Monthly Report for June through Mr. Samson, the local Agent; and has followed the same procedure for the past two months. It may be that the reports have been held back at Telegraph Creek. Whatever may have been the delay, I am forwarding his cheque today, and will advise him to send you directly in Ottawa the copy of his reports for July and August; the school has been officially closed at the end of August and had been conducted most successfully for three full months.

2.-In regard to the school to be conducted last winter at Klappan, I wish you would refer to my letter of Febr. 5 regarding the Klappan School at Telegraph Creek... promised to write to you concerning the whole situation after my visit to Telegraph Creek in March; I was prevented to do so, on account of my many travels and other pressing duties.

As a matter of fact, the Indians of Klappan failed to return to Klappan after New Years, and also failed to come back to town; so, it was impossible last winter to reach them. Father Forget profited, therefore, of this contretemps to go and visit the Indians of Cariboo Hide and Dease Lake, who were in an urgent need of spiritual assistance.

As to Father Turenne, he went to Shasley for two months and taught school there for some time, but did not think it worthwhile to send in any report on account of the contrary reports sent the previous year by the local Agent.

3.-I expect to be in Ottawa in October, and firmly expect by that time to have a full report on the whole school prospect at Telegraph.

Yours sincerely,

Bishop J.L. Coudert O.M.I., Vic. Ap. of Whitehorse

Dear Sir;

As the Rev. Father J.P. Tanguay has been teaching two months at
the Klappan School previous to his accident, I beg to advise you
to send him directly the cheque for his salary here in Edmonton, where
he is slowly recuperating from his accident. He has been teaching from
January 25 to March 9. You must by now have received the School Report
from Father Carpentier who has taken his place for the balance of the
School Term.

Father Tanguay is in urgent need of this money to help him pay
his hospital and doctor's bill; I am, therefore, returning to your Office
without delay Form T.D.1A duly signed by Father J.P. Tanguay so that
payment of the two months he has taught approximately may be made to
him without delay and without Tax Deduction.

The balance of the payment for the school period at Klappan
should be made to Father C. Carpentier, after you receive from him
a T.D.1A Form duly signed.

I have sent out Forms T.D.1A to all our missionaries conducting
Seasonal Schools, viz., to Father A. Dream; Cl. Carpentier; Jos. Forget; E. Mor-
issette. As soon as I receive them back duly signed and dated, I will
forward same to you.

Thanking you again for your kind services and the deep interest
manifested in our work on behalf of the Indians of Northern British Co-
lumbia and the Yukon, I remain, Dear Mr. Phelan,

Yours sincerely in Christ

J.L. Coudert O.M.I.

MONTHLY REPORT
Stikine Indian Agency - March 1942.

SCHOOLS

Klappan Seasonal. This school was visited March 9th and is being reported on in the regular form.

Building. Some improvement in the way of flooring, increased floor space and increased lighting, could be effected. Floor boards are hand-sawn spruce with edges and thickness very uneven causing wide cracks and uneven surface. The floor is difficult to clean and was rather dirty at the time of the inspection. With the aid of a whip-saw better floor lumber could be made and when an even surface was obtained, the whole floor covered with roofing paper and painted. The school-room could be enlarged by eliminating the present space of approximately 10 x 15' used as living quarters by the teacher and separated from the school-room by a firman partition. The teachers could be accommodated in the large lean-to at the rear of the school with very little fixing up. Lighting can be improved by enlarging existing windows.

Equipment. Desks and seats are also made of hand-sawn spruce and are very crude but serve the purpose. The blackboard consists of about 12 feet of rubberized cloth backed by more hand-sawn boards. Difficulty in transport precludes the possibility of providing better desks and blackboard unless an airplane is used which at present is very expensive.

Fuel. The teacher complained that only one or two of the Indians in camp had supplied wood. This matter was brought up at a meeting held during the visit to Isnat Lake and the Indians promised to supply all the wood needed for heating the school. Apparently the difficulty was that most of the men were away trapping most of the winter and it was not often that they were all in camp long enough to get together and cut and haul wood.

General; This little school is serving in a limited way the much needed education of Indian children in this Agency. In the past, few children have obtained more than the equivalent of two or three years public schooling and this lack is terribly noticeable when youths have great difficulty in writing even their names.

Dear Mr. Hoey:

I wish to thank you for your letter dated Feb. 9 inst., regarding repairs which have been made on the Klappan seasonal school. I am sorry to learn from the content of your letter that the mentioned improvements, so strongly recommended by your local Indian Agent, cannot be covered by any grant of the Department. It would seem reasonable in the part of the country such as ours, so very different and so far distant from Ottawa, that Government officials should show more confidence in their local representative, and grant them more authority to act.

With pleasure, however, I am taking note of your recognition of the Department's indebtedness to us in regard to the use of our mission buildings as school buildings; your proposition of allowing us a monthly rent of $15.00 for the use of our mission buildings in such places as Klappan and Dease Lake seems reasonable enough, and I fully agree to it, though I do not see why such an arrangement could not have any retroactive effect; if the Department officials feel under an obligation in our regard for the present in connection with the use of our buildings, I fail to understand why they would refuse to acknowledge such an obligation in our regard for the past. In accordance with your proposition, I am instructing our missionaries of Telegraph Creek immediately to present to Agent Sampson a bill in three copies for the rent of our mission house at Dease Lake, used as a school building from September last to the end of January just elapsed.

You may be aware, by this time, that, owing to fear of further sickness as well as to difficulties of communication between Telegraph Creek and the Klappan country, with the soft weather prevailing this winter, the Klappan Indians were unable to reach the place where we had, at such an expense, erected a decent mission school known by the Department as the Klappan School, referred to in my last letter; as a result the building will not be of any use this winter and no school shall be conducted at that point; consequently your proposition concerning the payment of a rent for the Klappan School Building cannot be of any help to us in the settlement of our debts.
I am taking occasion of this communication to urge again the officials of the Indian Department to take into serious consideration our oft repeated request that something be done early in northern British Columbia and the Yukon about the erection of a Catholic Boarding School and Preventorium for the destitute and orphan Indian children of that area whose number is daily increasing owing to the high mortality rate of the parents.

I also urgently ask for the erection of standard school buildings for the day schools conducted at Dease Lake and in the Klappan country; owing to the experience we had this winter with the Klappan Indians and their trapping ground so difficult of access, it would appear that a school building at Bulkley Lake might prove a better location, closer to Telegraph Creek and less expensive to put up than in Klappan. Pending the realization of this project we shall be ready, according to your proposition contained in your letter dated Feb. 8, to rent our present mission buildings for school purposes at the rate of $15.00 a month.

I wish to call the attention of the officials of the Department that according to our files, the question of a boarding school in the extreme northern portion of British Columbia or along the boundary line of the Yukon was taken up by our Church Officials with the Department of Indian Affairs as early as August 1925. I am sending copies of said files to Father Plourde for reference.

I sincerely hope to see such an important question finally settled along the lines suggested by our missionaries before the present generation becomes altogether extinct.

You may admire our patience and perseverance over these twenty years of begging and knocking at the door of the government for the sake of its most derelict wards; but, for our part, I must admit that we feel rather scandalized at the attitude of indifference, not to say of utter callousness, assumed by the responsible Officials of the Government in regard to the treatment of those entrusted to their care.

Thanking you for your own personal interest and earnest endeavours in the settlement of all afore mentioned problems, I remain,

Dear Mr. Hoey,

Yours sincerely in Christ

[Signature]

J.J. Coudert, M.I.
Catholic Bishop of the Yukon

Dear Bishop Coudert:

I have Your Lordship's letter of the 28th ultimo, with reference to repairs that have been made to the Klappan Seasonal School. I note the amount that you have expended, but I regret that present regulations do not permit our making a refund. All expenditures have to be authorized previous to being made and, in addition, supplies have to be purchased through our Purchasing Branch. I think you will realize that we could not possibly control expenditure if these regulations are not strictly followed.

I have given careful thought to the manner in which we could assist you in the work at this school, and it has been decided to allow rent for the building at the rate of $15.00 a month. Dear Sir:

I beg to acknowledge receipt of your communication dated January 19, in which you informed me that the necessary order-in-council has been obtained establishing the Teslin Lake R.C. Indian Day School.

I have immediately written to the Father in Charge to announce him the good news and forward to him the necessary forms to be completed by the teacher, Father A.Drean O.M.I., I instructed the latter to forward the completed forms directly to your office.

I wish to take occasion of this communication to inform you that, on the suggestion of Mr. Samson, the Indian Agent of the Stikine Agency, the priest in charge of the Klappan School had a new floor put in the Klappan School and new toilets built for the children; owing to the difficulties of transportation from Telegraph Creek to Klappan, the Indians had to make all the necessary boards by hand, which made the cost of those necessary improvements quite high; our missionary had to pay $400 approx. to the Indians of Klappan for that work. May I remind you that during the six years the mission house has been used for the school at Klappan not one cent has been contributed by the Department in the way of rent; I hope, therefore, that the Department will help us to pay for the improvements mentioned above. I requested Mr. Samson to mention the cost of said improvements in his next report to the Department.

Thanking you and Mr. Phelan for the interest your Department has shown of late in our difficult work in northern B.C. and the Yukon,

I remain,

Yours sincerely in Christ

Telegraph Creek, B.C.,
July 18, 1949.

W.S. Arneil, Esq., Indian Commissioner for B.C., Vancouver.

I am forwarding herewith requisitions for building materials for improvements to the Klappan Seasonal Indian School at Iskut Lakes Indian Camp. Father Studer, who taught this school from November to April this past season has asked that these repairs and improvements be undertaken this fall before the school opens.

It will be noted that the largest item of expense is the transportation by air, $300.00. This is apparently the least expensive, and most simple means of carrying the materials out. The school is about sixty miles to the east of Telegraph Creek, and is reached only by a very rough trail. Pack-horse transport has been considered, but this method is somewhat unreliable because of the uncertainty of securing enough horses at the right time. Hauling by dog-sled during the winter would also be just about as expensive as air transport. It is rather difficult to estimate the exact cost either by pack-horse or dog-sled.

With the possibility of a new school at Telegraph Creek to provide accommodation for Indian children I feel it might be well to defer action on the teacher's request for improvements until it is seen whether the families formerly staying at Iskut Lakes during the winter continue to do so with the new school operating. There is already talk by a few of these people, of staying in town this winter. It is also worthy of consideration that there is no certainty that they will travel to Iskut Lake every winter. Three winter seasons during the past eight years they have not gone all the way to Iskut Lakes, and the school has therefore not operated.

The improvements are to consist of: (1) covering old floor with felt and new shiplap flooring (2) caulking cracks between logs (3) painting interior walls & varnishing desks.

Sir,

Re:- Dease Lake Reserve - R.C. Summer Day school.

I beg to submit herewith School-teacher Moran's Report for the month of August, and also a special report from him covering the season's work.

Under Authority 158-1-1, June 4th, this school was to have continued until the 15th of September, but the Indian families went away, and so Mr Moran closed his work out there at the end of August. He was paid for three months only, leaving on the grant another half months pay at $100.00 per month (viz $50.00 not used). This amount he wishes to have allowed him when he opens up the Klappan Winter school, which he hopes to do on the 15th of this month (September). This is hardly possible however, as the time now will not allow.

It will be seen from his seasons report that the Dease Lake Summer School has not come up to expectations, and that they now wish to have a winter school in operation for the winter of 1939-1940. This means that there will be no summer school at this point for next summer.

However, the R.C. Mission have completed a very fine school House & Church combined, which can be used during the winter months proposed. Why this school has not been a success has yet to be discovered, and during the next few weeks such data will be obtained.

Mr Moran was informed that he would have to obtain all the Indians signatures to a Petition if the proposed winter school is considered, so that The Department can be certain that the Indian Families will send their children to the school, if considered, during the full winter term.

As the matter is not urgent now, data will be obtained and a further Report of this matter submitted later on.

I am,

Sir,

The Secretary,

Dept Mines & Resources,
OTTAWA.

DEASE LAKE INDIAN SCHOOL.

Telegraph Creek, B. C.
Sept. 2, 1938.

Mr. Harper Reed,
Indian Agent,
Telegraph Creek, B. C.

Dear Sir:

Herewith I beg to submit my report on the Dease Lake Indian Summer School for the term ending August 31, 1938.

Close observation has been given the advantages to be gained by the operation of a summer school and I have found that the cooperation to be had in winter schools is much in advance. This is not due to any lacking desire of the Indian to gain an education but more to the fact that these people are nomadic by nature and the summer months offer them every pleasantness to enjoy that nature.

At the beginning of the term (June 1st.) attendance was extremely good and the children showed much aptitude and attention to their studies progressing very favorably in all grades. Towards the middle of August preparations are begun for winter trap lines with the result that the entire family moves there for the remainder of the season.

In the fall the families return to the reservation and there remain throughout the entire winter.

At your request I have gone deeply into this matter with the parents and from them have received the unanimous approval for a winter school.

Personally, and from experience, I favor this latter system of education as the heat and long days of summer months greatly retard the progress of the children who otherwise and under other circumstances keenly delight in attending classes.

Should the Department favor the opening of a winter school at this point for the winter of 1939 it would be expedient to add that the enrollment would number a possible 17 pupils with an average daily attendance not less than 12 pupils.

The facilities to be had at Dease Lake are of the best and the school has been constructed to meet all the requirements for space and health of the children.

Very respectfully submitted,

J. E. Moran, Principal.
Extract from letter dated July 27th, 1938, from Indian Agent Harper Reed, original on file 160-5:

Dease Lake Summer Day School. This school was rather a venture for a small set of Indians living at Dease Lake. It was thought proper to start a school especially as Inspector Pragnell was requested to do so by these Indians, and they gave their promise to attend. Therefore Father Bosse went out there and started a school in an old cabin, much too crowded, but preferred to do that than use a special tent that was supplied. In the meantime the Church House was being erected, and last Fall completed. This Spring it is in use, being a very fine building. Dear Sir:

Copy of a letter dated December 31st, 1936, from Indian Agent Reed, of the Stikine Agency, to yourself upon the matter of part time schooling for the Indian children in his Agency, was forwarded to me.

As, to my mind, the matter of some kind of schooling, if only for a few months in the year, is most important to the Indian children in this Agency, I am writing to find out whether the Department has been able to decide anything in the matter. These children, if they are going to hold their own even in trapping with the white man, their prospects will be seriously handicapped if they cannot at least read and write and figure a bit.

According to Mr. Reed, and I know he is correct, the children residing on the Reserve at the head of Dease Lake are of mixed denominations. This might lead to the Anglican and Roman Catholic Missions acting at cross purposes. I should suggest as a way out of the difficulty that this would be an excellent opportunity for some young student from one of the Universities to earn a little money by holding school for three months up there. No doubt, our School Inspector could find such a lad. A tent for himself and a cook stove, and a large enough tent to hold class for about 10 or 12 children, with a movable blackboard and rough benches and tables, would be sufficient equipment, which equipment could be stored at Dease Lake when not in use. Further this is an excellent situation, as it is handy for getting stores, mail, etc., being only about half a mile across the lake. As a matter of fact I see no objection to the school tent being actually erected at Dease Lake itself and the children could go there by boat from the Reserve. It would have this advantage that the young school teacher would not be so lonely, and secondly, Mr. Harper Reed has a shack of his own which a school teacher could use.

If, therefore, we have some kind of day schools at Dease Lake, Klappan, Thaltan and McDames Creek, with also some teaching going on at Cariboo Hide, the Indians of this Agency will not suffer too great a handicapped when they grow up. I am very much interested in this matter and would like to hear what the Department thinks of it.

Yours truly,

(Geo. S. Pragnell)

During the inspection of The Stikine Agency, last summer, by G.S. Pragnell Esq., Inspector of Indian Agencies for British Columbia, the Indian Reserve at Dease Lk was visited. Here resides, during both winter and summer, about five indian families, who have between them, about a dozen children needing, and requesting schooling.

The Inspector considered that a rough summer-school should be established here, consisting of the usual school supplies, and conducted under tenting. All indians concerned considered this to be excellent arrangement, and were glad to know that a school was being considered.

The Inspector also thought that the R.C. Klappan Bay school Mission Schoolmaster might be able to conduct the proposed Dease Lake Summer School - during the summer.

The R.C. Mission of these parts, have already a small Cabin used as a church also, on the Dease Lake Reserve, and most of the Indian children belong to that Mission.

However two families have do not really belong to the R.C. Mission - that of Heals with four children who can attend school; and that of Billy Frank with three children who could attend, the latter having already attended the Anglican Mission at Tahltan Reserve. Heals wife is an R.C. and therefore his family can be considered such, but not that of Billy Frank's. It is felt that the Anglican Mission would mention the matter were Frank's children allowed to attend a school conducted by the R.C. Mission.

That some schooling should be afforded these children seems reasonable, and therefore in the Estimates now submitted appears an item under "Schools - Repairs etc" of $150-00 & Schools Equipment etc - a further sum of $70-00 for materials. A salary of $90-00 per month seems to be the lowest rate possible to offer a Schoolmaster.

May it be requested that instructions be allowed, as to if this Summer School is to be considered, or not, as up in these remote parts, much care and attention has to be given, which takes up much valuable time ere the opening up of such a school, if considered.

Your Reverence,

The Rev Father Carpentier O.M.I., who it is understood in now in charge of all R.C. Mission Affairs in these parts, has called at the Indian Office to know if the Department would consider the opening up, for the winter months, of the Dease Lake Mission School.

The Rev Father submits a list of about 20 children that might attend. It is thought that about ten of them might be "steady" at the school during the winter. On the list are some that do not belong so they deserve and it is allowed to put them. Trapping matters are greatly interfered with, and that as you know is a very vital matter in the winter life of the Indian families, and might lead to endless troubles with the B.C. Game Authorities. For the husband will trap where their families reside, and care should be exercised in obtaining school attendance "lists".

However the matter has been submitted to the Department, and it is considered here that if ten children are in attendance all winter long then the school should be in operation, and if not it should be closed. Also that the Indian families must supply all heating wood. That of course is an easy matter, for good wood is there but they should do something to help matters along.

Mr Moran, through Father Carpentier has suggested for a teacher, his lad Mr Stephen, a half-breed it is thought from some way. As you know the lad is young and in no way fit to take on such work. I am surprised that Mr Moran suggested such a person, it would lead to camp "rows". Some other Teacher must be found and may the person's name be submitted to Ottawa direct when decided upon.

The Salary has been mentioned as at $100-00 per month, as paid at this point last time the school was in operation, and that the school should start as at November first and close at the end of April 1940.

It is hoped that this will meet with your favour, and that this Office will be advised further in the matter.

HIS LORDSHIP,

Bishop Bunoz. O.M.I.

The list looks good, but it is certain that they will not all attend, and whilst they do come at first, a steady attendance cannot be expected. At least ten children will attend all the winter long. It is considered that these children might be allowed this schooling. The Salary allowed this Teacher was at $100-00 per month, during the summer of 1938. Should the operation of this school be considered it is thought that it should open November 1st, which allows the obtaining of fat winter meat and fish, as a supply for the winter. It should close about the end of March, as it is impossible to keep Indians in winter camps after that date. Moreover the late Teacher of this school (and also of the Klappan School) has suggested a Lad named Mc Stephen (a half-breed from down south and under his care here) to be the Teacher, but this is not thought at all correct and some other person will have to be appointed by His Lordship Bishop Bunoz. A Requisition List of supplies now needed was submitted under letter dated February 3rd 1939, and these supplies would be required should the school be opened up. My Lord;

The Indian Agent Mr. Reed, having promised us last fall the changing of the Summer school to a Winter School, the Rev. Father Rossie and I took steps in order to get the school house ready for a winter stay and to keep the people around it.

Last September I went and visited Mr. Reed to talk about the new teacher coming and the school supply necessary for the winter; but he answered we could not expect to get enough children around and the government could not support such an expense during the war time.

Re:- Dease Lake Seasonal School - Winter.

I beg to acknowledge receipt of your letter on the above subject, dated May 7th, regarding the question as to if the above school should be reopened for the coming winter - or not.

The date of September for reporting on the matter is rather late, as supplies etc would have to sent in over the Dease Lake Road etc, and some of the Indian families notified ahead of time so that they do not all move out to their trap grounds.

The situation here is slightly different from the other schools, for the Indians here mostly obtain their Revenue from Summer Wages earned from Whites. The Reserve is partly settled to meet those ends, and some families will not move away in any case. Moreover, the Fathers do not like to stay in Telegraph Creek over the winters, and so move out to Dease Lake. It is thought that were the school shut down, a Father would carry on the school anyways - with or without a Salary.

However, again should the War continue, the school could be shut down, and some families move out to their trap-ground, as done in the old days.

It is most thoroughly understood that in any event fuel wood must be supplied by the Indians concerned in all school affairs.

Sir,

Re. Dease Lake Winter School, R.C. Mission.

I beg to submit hereunder a short report on the above winter school located on the Dease Lake Reserve.

No doubt that the Department will remember that this school was marked as closed for this present winter, but that Father Carpentier, O.M.I., went out that way to spend the winter (it is thought now that he was induced to do so by the Hunter Frank family - Indians with the help of the local Store Manager at that point) and when there started up the Day-school, Bishop Bunoz then requested some payment for the Teacher, which resulted in the Department's letter to His Lordship, dated February 13th, 1940.

Therein is rightly stated that funds are only available for a Teacher's salary of $50-00 per month—for a period of six months. Also that an attendance of ten children or over must be maintained.

Father Carpentier called at this Office recently, and submitted his Reports, and as of January & February months—17 children attended.

This point presents difficulties, the children are there but these nomadic families have to go out trapping now and again, and then take their children with them. The result being that the attendance is erratic, but it is thought that a school should be provided in spite of that fact. A better attendance is possible later on. The final reports are not yet to hand, but about ten children will be in attendance, no doubt.

However, Father Carpentier mentioned that no wood had been provided for the school's use, and that it had cost him privately the sum of $60-00. A promise was given him that the Department would be advised of such a fact, but that the Indians there really should provide their own fuel, as they were camped there most of the year. He quite agreed with that idea, but could not make the Indians do this. No hope of payment for this wood cutting expense was given him, but regrets were expressed.

The best Indians out there are the Hunter Frank Family who are steadily employed by the H.B.Coy—they earn good wages, and have Radios etc. These Indians should give some help if they wish a school for their children, and the least they could do, would be to supply the cord-wood that is near-by and handy.

Father Carpentier mentioned that a Winter School at this Reserve brings in better returns than a summer school, and with this point of view your Agent fully agrees.

It is considered that Father Carpentier had better get together with the Indians out there, obtain a signed list of the children that will attend this school - if allowed for the future, and also a signed promise that the Indians provide their own school cord wood for the future. Also that of course the attendance will be of ten children or over all the winter.

The living conditions at this point are about the same, but perhaps a little more expensive than the living conditions at the Tahltan Reserve, and at this latter point the Teacher is allowed the salary of $90-00 per month. (summer school).

Dease Lake is the head of water-ways for the Inside generally, and therefore a lot of White Prospectors etc pass through this small settlement. Each and every one has some advice to give the Indians, and it is thought they believe that the Department simply has to supply them with any thing they require, when such is desired.

Should the Department consider a winter school at this point during the winter of 1940 - 1941, the period of such could well be for 3 months, ending on April 1st, 1941. At this time such families that wish to get out Beaver Trapping, or for the usual spring get-away, could leave the Reserve, and the school attendance would not be affected.

This school is a log building, a combination of mission missionaries residence and school. At present it is under the direction of C. Carpenter, O.M.I., of French birth, not long resident in Canada. His English is only fair, but he is, in my opinion, the best of the missionaries (of any religion) in the agency. The Indian children are fond of him and apart from the language difficulty, I believe he would be capable of doing excellent work if properly instructed.

I understand from the late Agent, Mr. Reed, that the Department expended about $500.00 in the construction of the school, the missionary at that time contributing some labour. The remarks previously made regarding combining church and school in one building apply equally to this school.

SCHOOLS:

Dease Lake Seasonal Day School. During the trip made to Dease Lake this month this school was visited. A separate report is being submitted on the usual form. This school closed December 19th after having operated since about the middle of last September.

R.H.S. Sampson,

Since writing the foregoing I had an opportunity of visiting Dease Lake School while awaiting plane transportation the school being in session under Father Carpentier O.M.I.

At that time, October 6th, there were present,

Grade 1a - 5 pupils
" 1b - 4 "
" 2 - 2 "

these ranged in age from 8 years to 12 years. Several reported absent due to illness, there being 21 on the roll, (11 girls, 10 boys.).

The children were examined by myself in reading and arithmetic. In reading only one girl, Mona Nehass, aged 12 was found able to read anything more advanced than "Two Little Indians". A few of the remainder could struggle through it with assistance from the teacher and the balance could not read it at all.

Writing was fair as compared with the reading.

The teacher was anxious to show the children's ability in arithmetic on the "Blackboard" but it was noticed that this was the simplest addition of two three figure numbers. When I substituted a figure involving a "carry over" they were unable to do the work, apart from Mona Nehass.

The children were anxious to sing and did very well, their repertories including "There's a Tavern in the Town". They were unable to sing "O Canada" at my suggestion, having no knowledge of the words. The Teacher is anxious to be supplied with a book of well known songs.

As previously stated, Father Carpentier is by far the best missionary engaged in this work in the Agency, and if the work in this school can be considered relatively high in comparison the rest must be indeed deplorable.

The children appeared to be well up to average in intelligence and I am satisfied that with proper tuition they would make considerable headway, even in a short term school.

This visit emphasizes the necessity of a survey and instruction by the Inspector of Indian Schools for this Province.

The alternative to this suggestion would be to endeavour to purchase the Missions' share in the schools but I would definitely not recommend this course as I believe that it would be far less expensive, even over a period of years, to pay an annual rental of $75.00 in the case of the Dease Lake and Klappan schools and possibly Lower Post or McDamn Creek if either operates, than to purchase these crude log buildings and try to improve them. From past experience it seems that the operation of these bush schools is quite provisional, depending as it does upon whether or not the Indians camp at the location of the school during the usual term. At the present time it seems that any extensive outlay for establishing day school buildings would be unwise, especially in the more remote locations because it is evident that the Indians in this area as a whole are still not inclined to settle permanently in one location. Their houses in and near Telegraph Creek for the most part are used only as stopping over places between their trapping and fishing camps. This has been more evident during the past fall and winter when these people have had to earn their living from the country, as they did prior to the freighting boom from 1941 to 1943 when supplies were going in by this route to Watson Lake Airport. It seems that the life-long habits of the Indians will not easily be changed, even to ensure the education of their children and the more or less temporary bush schools will probably have to serve, at least for the present.

I feel the Department should be aware of the excellent service given by Reverend Father Carpentier, O.M.I., the senior Roman Catholic missionary for the Cassiar district, during the many epidemics of sickness which have been prevalent amongst the Indians of this Agency since September, 1942.

In September, 1942, Father Carpentier spent many hours helping and nursing Indians on the Stikine Nomad Reserve at Telegraph Creek who were sick with a particularly severe type of influenza. His efforts in supervising the care of these people, without benefit of a doctor or nurse, were splendid.

At the expiration of the severe measles epidemic in January, 1943, amongst the Indians of the Iskut Lakes Camp, the Father again gave unselfish service in attending the wants of the many cases of lingering illness following the measles. He did this single handed as no medical or other help was available.

In May and June, 1943, another severe influenza epidemic struck the Telegraph Creek district and Father Carpentier did much to comfort and alleviate the suffering of sick Indians, visiting many infected homes and finally contracting the disease himself.

A dysentery epidemic broke out on the Stikine Nomad Reserve in August, 1943 and Father Carpentier was on hand to supervise and help stricken families, even spending whole nights watching with sick children. And at Dease Lake in November and December of the same year the Father, with only brief instructions, from Telegraph Creek, 75 miles distant by trail, nursed 12 children through this disease again and only one died and that one before the proper instructions for treatment had reached him.

Attention: Mr. P. Phelan,

My dear Mr. Phelan,

Seasonal day-schools are now being conducted in northern British Columbia and the Yukon at Dease Lake, Iskut Lake or Klappan, Cariboo Hide, McDame and Lower Post, and Teslin Lake.

At present, salary cheques are made out and mailed to each individual teacher. Due to distances and infrequent mail deliveries, His Excellency Bishop Coudert suggests that the cheques be made out to the order of his episcopal corporation as it is now being done for the McKenzie R.C. missions. This would simplify the Vicariate bookkeeping, and enable the treasurer to estimate the cost of each school as well as the amount which is allowed for its maintenance.

Since these seasonal Day-schools have been established, income tax has been deducted from each pay cheque made out to the missionaries. There are two reasons why this practice should cease: 1. because the teachers in all these schools are members of the Oblate Order and as such are obligated to remit to their Order all their earnings less what is essential for their upkeep; 2. in no case is the total income of each teacher within the range of taxable income. The missionaries concerned are Rev. Fathers C. Carpentier, J. Plaine, M. Bobillier, B. Arsenault, and P. Poulet. Apparently the cheques received by the above were issued by the agent of the Stikine Agency. Would it then be possible for you to trace the amount paid to each and to have the necessary income tax refund paid back to each of them.

Yours very truly,

[Signature]

Ottawa, July 3, 1944.

Dear Father Plourde:

I am in receipt of your letter of the 27th ultimo, with reference to Seasonal Day Schools in northern British Columbia and Yukon.

We understand that Klappan and Caribou Hide are operating during the winter months only.

Our files show that it was impossible to secure a teacher for the McDame School.

We have no record of any teachers operating schools this summer at Dease Lake, Lower Post and Iskut Lake. With reference to the latter we have no school of that name. Possibly there is another name for this particular point. We have received the name of the teacher at Teslin Lake, Reverend A. Dean, O.M.I.

Present regulations regarding salary cheques for teachers of Indian Day Schools, are that cheques are to be issued in favour of the teacher. We could, however, forward these cheques to some special address. If you will let me know to whom this should be sent arrangements will be made for the mailing of such cheques.

With regard to the third paragraph of your letter, I regret that no refund of any amount can be made by this Branch of any amount deducted for Income Tax purposes. Anyone considering himself entitled to a refund of Income Tax must file a return with the Income Tax Officials.

Recently a new form has been provided which covers the case of those only working for a short time. I inclose a supply of these forms and any teacher in a Seasonal School should complete this form and forward it to this office immediately upon beginning duties at a Seasonal School.

Re: Dease Lake - Father G. Carpentier has taught in Dease Lake up to February 16th of last year, and therefore, occupied our buildings for School purposes and used them up to that date. However, as the school was not approved for a period extending beyond January 31st, Father Carpentier thought it useless to send a report for the two extra weeks he taught.

Similarly last fall Father Cl. Carpentier went to Dease Lake for the purpose of conducting the School; he stayed there from the beginning of October to the middle of November, some four children attended the school the other Indians having gone down to the Alaska Highway last summer and having failed to come back for the winter. I instructed Father Carpentier to send in a report of the time he had taught those four children since he had gone purposely to Dease Lake to conduct school but he has been reluctant to do so under the circumstances and I doubt whether he will turn in any report for such a short period of teaching and for so few pupils.

Yet our buildings were used just the same during the stated periods for school purposes and I think that it would be only fair that we receive at least the money covering the rent and other extra services which were practically the same for four children as they would have been for twenty.

Therefore I still maintain my previous claim for three months rent at Dease Lake and other additional services (fuel and janitor's work) for the year 1945.

Dear Sir:

In January 1937 under authority 158-9-1, the sum of $200 was provided for lumber and other building materials for the Dease Lake School, Stikine Agency. Of this amount $72.16 was spent and an order for lumber amounting to approximately the full amount of the balance was placed by Mr. Harper Reed with Messrs. Robertson & Hackett, of Vancouver. Unfortunately, there was such a delay due to loss in the mails of certain letters, that before the order was finally received by the above mentioned firm, it was too late to complete the transaction before March 31st. I have asked Mr. Reed to re-apply for authority to cover the materials required so that purchase can be made and the order prepared for shipment as soon as navigation opens on the Stikine River. If the Department does not receive an application from Mr. Reed at an early date, it will likely be due to difficulty in getting mail out, in which case if the necessary authority is passed to this office, arrangements will be made for purchase of the lumber and other materials from here.

I beg to submit herewith a requisition for manual training tools and lumber for the Dease Lake Seasonal school which operates from September 1st to January 31st each year.

The attendance at this school has been good and the children are bright and eager to learn. In order to initiate the manual training work the tools supplied to the Tahltan Seasonal School were loaned to the Dease Lake School and a good start was made by the teacher although he was handicapped by lack of material. The teacher is very anxious to have a manual training class and has also organized a sewing and knitting instruction class for the girls. The boys show an inclination toward wood-work and manual training instruction would be valuable to them in later life when making boats, and doing general carpentry work.

It would be appreciated if the authorization for these tools could be expedited as much as possible because when Rev. Sir:-

There are approximately 36 Indian children of School age belonging to the North Takla Lake Band not attending the Lejac Residential School or any Day School for various reasons, the principal one being that these children with their parents move on to their trapping grounds late in August or early in September each year and are so far away that it is next to impossible to get them. Furthermore, the Lejac School can be filled with pupils much closer than these and for that reason the School authorities do not bother much about them.

Under the circumstances I am going to recommend to the Department that a Summer School be established at Takla Landing along the same lines as those at Fort McLeod and Fort Grahame at present. The length of the term at Takla could be four months instead of three.

The Indians are prepared to build a school if the Department will assist with the roof, floors, windows and doors, the total cost of which should not exceed $200-00.

There is a building available which we could get along with for one year and which we could rent for $10-00 per month. It fact it might be advisable to do that anyway for a year or two until we could decide on the definite success or failure of the scheme. Of course a certain amount of lumber would have to be sent up anyway the first year to make desks.

If you would please take this matter into consideration and advise if anything could be done about establishing a school at this point next year I would be greatly obliged. If there is I could do a lot of preliminary work during the winter, such as notifying the parents through their Missionary at Christmas of the probable date that the school would open.

I didn't mention this school in my Estimates as I did not consider at that time that the question was developed far enough among the Indians, although it has been discussed with them by me for the past two years. However, recent advice lead me to believe that the Indians have taken to the idea and are ripe for us to proceed.

Your obedient servant,

R.H. Moore,
Indian Agent.

Ottawa, November 17, 1936.

Dear Sir:

I have your letter of the 9th instant, requesting that a summer school be established at Takla Landing, for the benefit of the Indian children belonging to the North Takla Lake Band, and that this school be conducted along the same lines as the summer school at Fort McLeod and at Port Grahame.

The Department will be prepared to give favourable consideration to the conducting of a summer school for a period of four months next summer, provided the building which you state is available will be satisfactory for classroom purposes. Besides payment of teacher's salary, we would allow rental for use of the building, at the rate of $10 per month, during the period the school is in operation.

Should this school prove a success, the question of assisting in the erection of a building, by supplying flooring material, windows, doors, etc., could then receive consideration.

It is assumed that the Indians of this Band are Roman Catholic. If the church authorities could nominate, in due time, a qualified teacher, we would be prepared to allow salary at the same rate as has been paid at the two above named summer schools. You might advise

advise when you would recommend that the school should open, and, in due time, you should forward a list of the classroom equipment that would be necessary. Please state, also, the cost, including freight, of the lumber that would be necessary to make desks.

Sir:—

I recently returned from North Takia Lake where I had an opportunity of visiting the summer school and checking up on how it was received by the Indians generally and the parents and children in particular.

I am pleased to be able to report that the School, so far, is getting along splendidly. There has been 100% attendance every day since it opened and we are going to have 40 children enrolled by the end of this week, when I was there last week there were 36. The teacher informed me that with one or two exceptions none of the children had ever attended school before so you can imagine what a boon this summer school is to these Indians who are really too far away from Lejac to send their children there. After my return from Takia I had to order some more lumber to make another desk (which seats 8) and for that reason I may run a few dollars over the amount of $50-00 allowed in your letter of April the 6th. last, File No. 163-26-1. However, I will not need to use the $15-00 which I asked for stove pipes as this will not be necessary.

I expect to pay another visit to Takia Landing about the middle of July and I will give you further particulars of the progress being made after my inspection at that time.

Please refer to official letter No. 163-26-1 dated November 17th, 1936 with reference to establishing a summer school for four months at Takla Lake, B.C.

I have arranged that Mr. R.J. Downey, who was teaching last year at Fort Grahame, do the teaching this year at Takla. He is a very good teacher and his previous experience will be valuable in opening a new school. A new teacher will be sent to Fort Grahame in his place but I am not quite sure yet who it will be but as soon as I know definitely you will be advised.

We can get the building at Takla for $10.00 per month and it should be opened on or about May 15th., next.

If the Department would please arrange to send me a supply of necessary classroom equipment, for 36 to 40 children, the majority of whom are beginners or in the lower grades, with only about six in grade four or five, I would be greatly obliged. A list very much like that sent to Mr. Shiel at Fort Grahame Schools would do, as well as the additional list sent in April last, (please refer to Mr. Shiel's letter of April 10th, 1936, File No. 163-12-4). Coloured chalk as well as white should be sent, also blackboard brushes, scissors for cutting out and a School Register.

An expenditure of approximately $35.00 will be necessary for janitor's supplies, including hand bands, soap and paper towels; this will include freight.

It will take approximately fifty dollars to cover the cost of material for the desks plus the freight from Vanderhoof to Takla, as well as fifteen dollars for a cheap stove and stove pipes. One hundred dollars altogether should cover everything.

The supplies can be shipped next month and I would like to have authority to purchase the lumber & other supplies as we may have to send out for some of them.

Sir:

I beg to submit herewith a general report of affairs in this agency during the month of July 1938.

The school at Tackla was visited and a meeting held with the parents. I told them that unless the parents took more interest in the school and saw to it that their boys and girls attended regularly, and on time every school morning, I would recommend that the school be closed this year and not opened again next. I understand that my talk and threats had some effect for the attendance has been doubled since I was there and things are very much improved. I am not so sure that the new teacher wasn't to blame, as he is much too lax in his discipline and does not seem to have any control over the children when they are out playing during recess. In watching the teacher attend to ordinary routine in the school he is, I think, quite capable, but he certainly can stand to be a lot stricter with the pupils during recess and while they are on the school grounds. I told the teacher this when I was there and think that he may improve, but he is a timid young chap anyway and I am not so sure that he will ever be much of a success in an outlying seasonal school like Tackla anyway. Outside of that I think real progress is being made in the school and it is kept spotlessly clean and neat.

Practically all the Indians of the Takla Band obtained work at the Bralorne Mines, some 45 miles from Takla, and took their families with them, as a result the attendance has been very poor indeed.

Dear Sir:

According to letters of March 22nd, and April 20th last, from your Department, I was informed that the salary for teaching at Tahla was $90.65 a teaching month, plus bonus, for a period of three months. You stated: "The schools are operated for three months." It was on such information and understanding that I assumed the position and endeavored, at great odds, to keep the school open. Then when my efforts to keep the school going failed, you ordered it closed.

A short while ago I received from your Office, cheques covering the first two months. Today I received, supposedly as a final settlement, a cheque for the sum of $37.36. Needless to say, I refuse to accept this as final payment. First of all, I was employed by the month, for three months. The expense
entailed in taking such a position would have ruled out acceptance of such a position for any shorter length of time. Secondly, the Dept. ordered the school closed when, through incompetency, they could not control the children's attendance at school. Thirdly, I had been informed by other teachers, and you confirmed it, that three teaching months was considered 60 days. I operated the school for 52 days. Last year the school wasn't even operated for 60 days either, yet the teacher was fully compensated. Fourthly, the amount of money sent me is equivalent to slightly more than a third of a month's salary. Yet, I had put in 10 days when the school was ordered closed. And ten days is a good deal more than a third of a month! (a teaching month).

I trust that I shall receive very shortly a cheque for $67.94 covering the balance of my salary.

Sincerely yours,

Nancy J. Befoe.

Re: Takla Landing Seasonal School
Your file No. 859-1 (E)

Replying to your letter of March 9th.

In view of the extremely poor attendance at the above mentioned School in the past few years, I would recommend closing the School completely.

It is necessary for the Members of this Band to migrate to obtain work during the summer season, and they take their families along. The logical place for the children is in the Lejac Residential School and an attempt will be made to enroll a considerable number at Lejac for the 1949-50 term.

On our annual visit to this remote Reserve, next June, we will pick up the books and equipment for use in other Schools in the Agency.

R. Howe,

Dear Sir:

With reference to your letter of the 31st ultimo the Department approves the rental of a house from Pierre John at a rental of $15.00 a teaching month for purposes of conducting the Takla Landing Seasonal School.

You may also purchase a heater for this school at a cost of $36.40.

Yours truly,

R.A. Hoey,
Supt. of Welfare & Training.

Mr. R. Howe,
Indian Agent,
Vanderhoof, B.C.
Sir:

I wish to apply herewith for authority to rent the house of Pierre John, North Takla Lake Indian Reserve for summer school purposes. The building is far more suitable than the house of Jean Marie formerly rented for school purposes.

The Pierre John House is large, roomy and well ventilated, centrally located and may be rented for $15-00 per month, $5-00 a month less than we usually pay. Also the living quarters in the building will be at the disposal of the teacher, rent free, if desired.

It is necessary however to install a heater in the large room which will be used as a class-room and I would ask that authority be granted to purchase a No. 234 "Famous Heater" and accessories at a cost of $35-40, F.O.B. Takla Landing. The equipment is necessary regardless which house may be used.

Attached hereto tender for heater, pipes, metal mat and thimbles from L.R. Dickinson, Merchants, Fort St. James, B.C.

Your obedient servant,

The following solutions to meet the problem of the education of the children of the local reserves were put forward and carefully considered.

(1) Have children attend the Residential School.

(2) Have children attend the Residential School as day pupils and receive mid-day meal at the school.

(3) Provide a day school on the Opetchesahlt Reserve or at a point approximately midway between the two reserves, that is, cheshahlt and Opetchesahlt.

With reference to solution (1), our experience would not justify a continuation of this arrangement. It has not been successful. Solution (2) would involve mixing up the Residential School and Day School pupils, which is not desirable inasmuch as it would most certainly cause discontent amongst the former owing to the wide freedom enjoyed by day school pupils in comparison with the restrictive character of residential school life. Dr. Morrison, Mr. Ashbridge and the writer are agreed that solution (3) appears the best under the circumstances.

The Indians suggested that the old church building on the Opetchesahlt Reserve could be repaired to meet our needs until such time as a new school could be built. I examined the building referred to by the Indians and concluded that it was too far gone to warrant the extensive repairs that would be necessary to put it in shape. The building has been unused for many years and appears to be on the verge of collapse. However, I instructed Mr. Ashbridge to secure a report from a competent builder on the condition of the building. The Agent's report in this connection has now come to hand and is to the effect that the building is beyond repair and should be torn down. Mr. Ashbridge is being asked to ascertain if there is any suitable accommodation in the locality that could be secured on a temporary basis for use as a classroom.

Joint Meeting of the Sheshahlt and Opetchesahlt Bands

As already stated the Indians of these Bands requested a meeting with the Commissioner to discuss school matters. The meeting was presided over by Mr. Indian Agent Ashbridge and was orderly throughout. The particular matters which the Indians wished to discuss had to do with the following:

(a) Visiting hours at the school.
(b) Allowing children out of school to visit in Alberni and Port Alberni with their parents.
(c) Use of the wash rooms on the girls' side.

I found the regulations covering (a) and (b) quite reasonable and in line with those in force in other residential schools. The Indians were informed that these
rules were designed to protect the health and general well-being of the pupils and, although some exception might be made because of unusual circumstances, any general relaxation of them could not be permitted. With respect to (c), it was disclosed that the use permitted of these wash-rooms was altogether too limited and, in some cases, had resulted in the children having to go elsewhere to relieve themselves. I instructed the Principal to remove the existing restriction and permit the use of these facilities consistent with the needs of the children. It transpired that Mr. Caldwell was not familiar with the restrictions placed on the use of these wash rooms which had been imposed by the girls' matron, Mrs. Mackenzie, apparently without consulting him.

The question of establishing a day school to meet the needs of the local reserves was discussed at considerable length and resulted in the meeting unanimously declaring in favor of a day school being established on the Opetchesah Reserve or some suitable alternative site between the town of Alberni and the residential school. There were twenty Indians eligible to vote present at the meeting, 16 from the Sheshat Band and 4 from the Opetchesah Band.
MEMORANDUM TO:
The Indian Commissioner for B.C.

From Inspector of Indian Agencies

Re: Day School, Alberni

In accordance with your instructions I visited Opetchesht Indian Reserve No. 1 at Alberni in connection with the proposal to establish a day school there to serve children of that Reserve and Seshart Indian Reserve No. 1, in order to relieve school administrative problems at Alberni Indian Residential School and make available accommodation at the school, now taken up by these pupils, for children from Reserves having no educational facilities.

There is an old church building situated on the north side of the highway following the river and at the s.w. corner of the Reserve, which it was proposed at one time to repair and convert into a school house. I examined the building and agree with the Indian Agent's report of March 28th, 1945, to the effect that it would cost less to tear it down and rebuild. It is a very old structure in an advanced stage of interior and exterior decay. I would recommend against using any material that could be salvaged from it in a new school building. If it is torn down this site would make an excellent location for a new school building as it is a good building site, mostly covered with brush and reasonably easy clearing as many of the larger trees could be left for shade and ornament. Indians could be employed for clearing, unless the Agent's proposal to me to have it done with a bulldozer was adopted.

As stated, the highway is on the south of this site and there is an excellent road along the west boundary of the Reserve. There is an excellent view of the river from the site and the surroundings could be made quite attractive. As the Indian houses on this Reserve facing the highway are fairly modern design bungalows with good gardens, the whole would create a good impression of the Reserve to travellers using this main road.

If it is intended to build a school I would recommend that we acquire from the Indians a rectangular area of about one to one and a half acres on this corner, which would be bounded on the south by the main road, on the west by the side road and east boundary of the Reserve, on the north by existing Indian cultivation and on the east by a north and south boundary about three...
hundred feet from and parallel with the west boundary. This would probably include a small area immediately east of the old church on which some Indian may have a claim as it contains an old, small, unoccupied and dilapidated building surrounded by a heavy second growth of brush. If necessary, compensation should be paid to the Indian claimant, which would probably not exceed $100.00.

According to the Commissioner's report of March 31, 1945, on Alberni Indian Residential School, there are 31 children of school age on Seshart Reserve (about 1 1/4 miles distant) and 13 on Opetchesat Reserve, total of 44, with preschool children of 33 and 12 respectively, total 45. This would point to the possible future need for two classrooms and the design of any new building could provide for a necessary addition, or possibly a basement classroom.

There is an acute shortage of housing accommodation in the district, which will probably continue well into the post war period due to the expansion of the timber industry here. Further, any school should be planned with a view to its becoming an Indian community center with a resident teacher, particularly if these may be employed on a year round basis at some future time. It is much easier to secure fully qualified teaching personnel where the accommodation problem is disposed of. Such a school in this location would probably cost $6,500.00 to $7,500.00, and could be patterned after the Bella Bella or Kitimat schools if a two room and community structure. The entire cost, equipped, would probably run well up towards $10,000 or two thirds of the amount for a one room school with residence. A simple one room school without residence would probably cost about $3,000.00.

These suggestions are made as, with the Indian Agent, I was unable to find that any temporary accommodation was available.

In my report on the Alberni Indian Residential School dated March 31st reference was made to the need of a Day School in the vicinity of the Residential School to provide accommodation for Indian school children of the Sheshahht and Opetchesahht Reserves not attending the Residential School. During a discussion of the matter, a site on the Opetchesahht Reserve was suggested as suitable for this purpose, following which the matter was referred to the Indian owners by the Agent for consideration. The Band met on April 2nd and following an explanation of the requirements of the Department by Mr. Ashbridge passed the attached resolution indicating their willingness to surrender sufficient land for school purposes.

Mr. Inspector Coleman discussed the subject with Mr. Ashbridge during a recent visit to Alberni and I enclose a copy of his memorandum, with accompanying photographs of the site, for your information. If it transpires that the equipment at Ucluelet, to which Inspector Coleman refers, is not needed at that point arrangements can be made for its transfer to Alberni.

I should like to suggest the Department proceed to secure the necessary authority for the establishment of a Day School on the Opetchesahht Reserve in order that construction may proceed once funds and materials become available.

4. By the total number of school days in the quarter is meant the number of days in the quarter exclusive of Saturdays and Sundays. All authorized holidays will be allowed.
5. The standing of each pupil must be signified by inserting opposite his or her name the figure 1 in the column designating the particular grade.
6. No names other than those of Indian children are to be included in this return.
7. The Quarterly Return must end on the 31st March, 30th June, 30th September, and 31st December respectively, and be immediately thereafter in each case transmitted to the local Indian Agent.
8. When owing to the number of pupils, the form of Return is not long enough to contain all the names, use another form, paging it as No. 2, and carry forward all totals, placing them in the proper columns. Do not increase the length of the form by pasting another, or portion of one, to it.
9. The average daily attendance during the quarter may be ascertained by dividing the total number of days attendance of all the pupils by the number of days school was open in the quarter.
10. Should the school be closed at any time during the quarter, the reason must be given in the column for remarks for such day or days.
11. The school must be opened and closed punctually at the hours approved of by the Department.
12. This form to be used for Day Schools only.

INSPECTOR'S REPORT ON ALBERNI INDIAN DAY SCHOOL

United Church: West Coast Agency

Date of inspection: March 13, 1928.

Number of pupils present: Boys - 5 Girls - 2 Total - 7

Number of classrooms: One. This is the old Primary Room of the Indian Residential School. There is a basement which contains about 16 small single desks and a quantity of Manual Training equipment and several Singer sewing machines none of which are in use at the present time.

Number of desks in each classroom: There are twenty-six single desks. This includes some eight almost new larger desks which were obtained for the older children when this school was established last September.

Name of teacher: Miss Ketha Pitts. Age 31.

Health: Very Good

Remarks relative to methods employed by teacher:

Miss Pitts was trained at the Winnipeg Normal School. She holds a Second Class Certificate in the Province of Manitoba and a First Class Certificate in B.C. Miss Pitts attended a Summer School in Victoria in the year 1920 and received credit for Primary Work.

Her experience includes some nine years in the Primary Division of the Alberni Indian Residential School and one year here, having been appointed to her present position in September 1927. I may say that neither the Indian Commissioner for British Columbia or I were consulted when this appointment was made. It has not proved a very suitable one as Miss Pitts has had very little experience in the teaching of older pupils and despite all that I have done for her the attendance here has fallen off. This she puts down to the Indian parents taking the children out of the local village during seasonal migrations. A teacher more experienced with older children and one who had no connection with the very unhappy conditions at the former Indian Residential School would have made a much better success in this Indian Day School.

I wish to say that Miss Pitts is doing as well as she knows how, and has made an effort to follow my suggestions. She has limited her use of corporal punishment. The schoolroom is clean and bright. A number of very good posters have been constructed by the teacher. I am very sorry for this girl as had she been in another school her work would have met with much greater success.

I am not satisfied that the former Principal of the Alberni Indian Residential School, the Reverend Mr. Pitts, father of the present Day School teacher, has done his best to encourage a good attendance at this Day School.

Miss Pitts told me today that a Day School could not be a success here as the people moved about so much. I explained that her duty was to see to it that all possible pupils did attend and to leave the question of the policy of the Department to be settled by others.

A male teacher who had no previous connection with Alberni and with some years of successful experience would make a great difference at this school, though I do think that Miss Pitts should not be too greatly condemned for the possible
political and other actions of her father.

Remarks relative to the examination of the pupils.

As there were only seven children present four of whom were in the lower part of Grade 1 and the three most advanced only in Grade 3 I can say very little about the actual work done this year.

In Reading Grade 3 are working at Highroads Reader Book Z and also using with success the Reading Exercise Work Book suitable for their Grade. The children's reading was fairly good. The little people in Grade 1 who were present are just beginners and as such read in a satisfactory if rather slow manner.

Far too little ORAL LANGUAGE has been done. I again taught a type lesson to aid the teacher. Oral Language in the case of Indian children who do not speak English at home is so necessary that I fail to understand why teachers do not give much greater time to it. The English Usage and Composition Work Books in Language are used with some success in Grade 3, who however failed to convince me that they knew much about the proper way to answer simple questions, or to speak about the simple objects to be found in the classroom.

Writing is satisfactory. I suggested material for printing in Grade 1C and found that the change to script was being made correctly in Grade 1C and to ink in Grade 2. I asked that Grade 3 should reduce the size of the writing to the usual Half space taught in this Grade.

In Arithmetic I taught a Demonstration Lesson in Simple Problems for Grade 3. The teacher took notes. Other suggestions were also made. Grade 3 has made some progress and is up to standard in Arithmetic. Grade 1 is rather weak. Quick drills will be still necessary with all the pupils.

I found that the new Pathways in Science texts were being used in the school. Grade 3 has finished Book 2 and is now working in Book 3, while Grade 1 is listening to the stories in Book 1.

Some Art Work has been done. I explained with some care the object of the forthcoming Arts and Crafts Exhibition and instructed the teacher and older children with regard to suitable work for this exhibition. This school will be represented by a few baskets and woven mats, and by a few drawings.

This is a bright clean schoolroom. There is plenty of work on the boards for the children. The teacher has satisfactory control of the pupils. In reply to my question she stated that she had only resorted to corporal punishment once this year.

One boy REGGIE GUSO Age 9 in Grade 1A broke his wrist on Friday afternoon March 11th, the teacher informs me. This boy was permitted to go home with the other small pupils at 2.30 p.m. as is correct for Grades 1 and 2 in 1C. The teacher was still in the schoolroom with the older pupils till 5.30 p.m. Some time during the interval 2.30 p.m. to 5.30 p.m. Reggie fell off a swing and broke his wrist. A Doctor Jones who is perhaps a substitute medical officer here has the case in hand and though I did not see this little boy, I understand that he is again coming to school with his wrist and arm in a plaster cast.

I do not believe that Miss Pitts was to blame in this though an experienced rural school teacher would have seen to it that the small children started for home at 2.30 p.m. and did not play at the school without supervision.
Attendance problem: remedies suggested, etc.

The attendance has not been very good, and appears to be even worse now than when the school was first opened.

I have instructed the teacher in the proper manner of entering records in the school register.

General Remarks:

The attendance is highly unsatisfactory.

The school is not a success.

It is essential that the teacher at such a school as this believes in the possibility of making an Indian Day School a success, even under rather adverse circumstances. Miss Pitts being so closely connected with the late Indian Residential School, which itself was anything but a success, should not have been chosen as the first teacher of the Day School here. Miss Pitts has done her best in a limited way but would do far better in a "Provincial School".

The question of transfer of Mr. and Mrs. Von Storch from Ucluelet to take charge here should I think be taken into consideration. Mr. Von Storch has been quite long enough at Ucluelet and Mrs. Von Storch is no longer required there as Field Matron. If Mr. Von Storch had done better work at Ucluelet this last year I should have recommended this transfer, as it is I can only suggest that he be moved here with the consent of the United Church as a temporary teacher, as from September 1938.

The future of this Alberni Day School is bound up with the Department's policy in regard to the building of an Indian Residential School at some point on the West Coast. Any appointment at the Alberni Indian Day School for the school year 1938-39 should be in my opinion of a strictly temporary nature.

The present standing of this school is only "Fair".

(sgd.) Gerald H. Barry,
Inspector of Indian Schools, B.C.

Somass Hotel,
