March 18, 1938.

Major D. M. MacKay,
Indian Commissioner,
P.O. Box 8,
Vancouver, B.C.

Dear Major MacKay:

I am forwarding herewith my report on the Alberni Indian Day School, West Coast Agency, which I inspected this morning.

I am not satisfied with the condition of this school. The teacher considers that no Day School would be a success here. This is of course the opinion of her father, the Reverend Mr. Pitts, the late Principal of the Alberni Indian Residential School.

When Dr. Wilson nominated Miss Pitts for her present position as teacher of the Alberni Indian Day School and forwarded her name through United Church officials to the Indian Affairs Branch, I was not consulted nor were you as far as I know.

The fact of the matter is that in conversation with Dr. Wilson later it came out that he had never seen the girl, and that he had telephoned to Mr. Indian Agent Ashbridge asking if the nomination of Miss Pitts would be satisfactory. Dr. Wilson, Superintendent for the United Church Missions south of the Bella Coola-Bella Bella line, informed me that Mr. Ashbridge said it was satisfactory for Miss Pitts to be nominated to the Department.

Mr. Ashbridge asked me at the same time or shortly afterwards to protest the appointment of Miss Pitts to the Department. I told him I could not do any such thing as I had not been consulted. You will remember that it was about this time that I suggested that all nominations for Indian Day School teachers be made through your office in order that the Department might be properly informed with regard to qualifications of candidates. This has since been arranged and is working very well indeed.

Mr. Ashbridge would no doubt like a change of teachers made here at the end of the present school year. His wishes do not carry much weight with me as he is entirely responsible for the present state of things at this school, where Miss Pitts should never have been appointed, but once appointed must be given every consideration. Her work has not been poor enough to justify a dismissal, and not good enough to make a success of the school under the political conditions in Alberni. I must just leave it to you and the Indian Affairs Branch to decide what it is best to do under the circumstances.

Mr. Caldwell, Principal of the Ahousaht Indian Residential School, considers that the Rev. Mr. Pitts is doing all he can to keep the children away from the Alberni Day School to force the Department to build a Residential School at Alberni. I am not prepared to say that this is a fact.

Yours very truly,

Gerald H. Barry,
Inspector of Indian Schools, B.C.

Miss Pitts being so closely connected with the late Indian Residential School, which itself was anything but a success, should not have been chosen as the first teacher of the Day School here. Miss Pitts has done her best in a limited way but would do far better in a "Provincial School".

The question of transfer of Mr. and Mrs. Von Storch from Ucluelet to take charge here should I think be taken into consideration. Mr. Von Storch has been quite long enough at Ucluelet and Mrs Von Storch is no longer required there as Field Matron. If Mr. Von Storch had done better work at Ucluelet this last year I should have recommended this transfer, as it is I can only suggest that he be moved here with the consent of the United Church as a temporary teacher as from September 1938.

The future of this Alberni Day School is bound up with the Department's policy in regard to the building of an Indian Residential School at some point on the West Coast. Any appointment at the Alberni Indian Day School for the school year 1938-39 should be in my opinion of a strictly temporary nature.

The present standing of this school is only "Fair".

Port Alberni, B.C.

Dear Major MacKay:

I am forwarding herewith my report on the Alberni Indian Day School, West Coast Agency, which I inspected this morning.

Mr. Indian Agent Ashbridge was with me during the whole of this inspection.

While the general standing of the school is not very satisfactory, the teacher, Mr. Glover, has been kind to the children and interested the older pupils to a much greater extent than the former teacher, Miss Pitts. The attendance has therefore been somewhat better.

Either hot soup or hot cocoa is served at Noon.

The room is certainly in a much less untidy condition than on the occasion of my last inspection. This report should I consider be read in connection with that forwarded to you on December 8th 1938. There has as you will note been some improvement since then, but I do not consider that Mr. Glover will ever be a success with small Indian pupils for he has little idea of the energetic teaching necessary to produce any worth while results in Primary Grades. He is a rather negative type of teacher.

I do not consider that it will be necessary for the Department to take any action to have him replaced by a better qualified instructor, for of course this day school will be absorbed in the new Alberni Indian Residential School now building.

I wish to note here for your future reference that very few if any of the Manual Training tools supplied to the former Alberni Residential School are available for the new school when it opens.

The following desks are however available:
- 11 only Single School Desks No. 5
- 21 only Single School Desks No. 4
- 11 only Single School Desks No. 3
- 1 only Single School Desk No. 2

The new Residential School appears to be of standard design and to have reached a stage of construction, as far as the main building is concerned, of the completion of the cement work for the basement. It occupies a site roughly equivalent to that of the older school.

Yours very truly,

Dear Major Mackay:

I am forwarding herewith my report on the Alberni Indian Day School, West Coast Agency, which I inspected this morning.

Mr. Indian Agent Ashbridge was with me during the inspection.

The present teacher, Mr. J. Glover, B.A., was moved here in September from Kletmu, where he had been for three years. I hope that the change will be good for Mr. and Mrs Glover who had been quite long enough in Kletmu. Their children will benefit in any case as they are able to attend High School at Alberni and there was no school for them to go to at Kletmu.

The Alberni Indian Day School needs to be kept in a much more tidy condition. Papers and books were all over the place. Pupils coats and hats were in the actual schoolroom and the large windows of the room were closed though the day was mild and damp. I of course pointed out these matters to the teacher and had the windows opened.

Though a trained teacher Mr. Glover so far has not made much of a success with small children. I have done what I could for him, and hope that when I next visit the school there will be a great improvement.

INSPECTOR'S REPORT ON ALBERNI INDIAN DAY SCHOOL

United Church West Coast Agency

Date of inspection: December 8, 1938.

Number of pupils present:
Boys 12
Girls 12
Total 24

There were only three children absent, one being in Grade 5 and two Beginners.

Number of classrooms: One. This is the old Primary Room of the Indian Residential School. There is a basement which contains about 14 small single desks and a quantity of Manual Training equipment. There are also several Singer sewing machines which the Indian Agent proposes to make use of in the Day Schools of the Agency. I certainly consider he should do this as the equipment will only spoil by disuse. Many of the Manual Training tools would appear to have been lost (?) at the time of the fire. Saws and hammers to mention only two items appear to be missing.

I hope that later the boys attending this Alberni Indian Day School will be taught Manual Training in the basement of the school.

Number of desks in each classroom: There are twenty-eight desks larger desks now about a year in use which it was necessary to get to accommodate the older pupils when the day school was established in September 1927.

Name of teacher: Mr. James B. Glover B.A.

Health: Good.

Remarks relative to methods employed by teacher:

Mr. Glover was educated at the University of Alberta where he obtained his B.A. He was trained at the Calgary Normal School and holds a First Class Certificate in Alberta. His experience includes three years as teacher of the Indian Day School at Klemtu. He has been here on transfer since September 1938.

Mr. Glover has managed to interest the older children who would not attend when Miss Pitts was in charge of the Day School. He has in fact greatly increased the attendance.

This teacher is I believe trying to carry out my suggestions made from time to time during inspections at Klemtu. He does not think very clearly and has not any definite idea even now of how much each child knows or does not know.

I found a few children in wrong Grades and Mr. Glover appeared none too certain just which Grade certain pupils were in as they appear to work with more than one Grade.

Every possible help was given and as the teacher took notes I hope for an improvement by next spring, when I shall try to visit this school again.

Remarks relative to the examination of the pupils:

Singing is fairly good. Some pupils sing very flat. Writing is in general satisfactory. It is good in Grade 3. Reading from Grade 3 to 6 inclusive is good. Grade 1 do not read well. Grade 1C and 1D are backward. They may not have been in school very long as yet for some came late.

Language Work Books are in use.

I asked that definite lessons be given daily in Health and suggested where material could be obtained.
Remarks relative to the examination of the pupils continued:

Arithmetic is about average. I tested the older pupils in the Fundamentals with the All, Canada Test.

Grade 6 made a Mid Score of 29 Norm 30
Grade 5 made a Mid Score of 22 Norm 25
Grade 4 made a Mid Score of 14 Norm 19
Grade 3 made a Mid Score of 9 Norm 8

In Vocational Work Mrs Glover is teaching the girls to sew. The boys will later be started on simple Manual Training. It is not much use talking of Arts and Crafts till the teacher has organized his academic work better. I however supplied him with a large sheet of Indian designs for use in Art Work. Later these can be applied to Manual Training projects.

I noticed that the older girls help with the Noon lunch of cocoa soup etc., prepared in this school.

The response to my own teaching was not very good. I believe that the older pupils are regaining some ability to express themselves. Most were at the Residential School here and there learned very poor classroom manners. It will take years to get over the very poor training given at the old Alberni Indian Residential School. I very much doubt that the training given at that school was of any great advantage to the children. In an Indian Day School the Indian Agent and Inspector of Schools have much greater opportunities to make certain that real instruction is being given to the children.

The teacher's control of this class is "Fair".

Attendance problem: remedies suggested, etc.

Attendance has greatly improved since Mr. Glover took charge of the school. This does not appear below.

Dear Mr. Neill,

I have, for acknowledgment, your letter of July 22nd, addressed to Mr. Pratt, in which you express disappointment at our failure to supply you with information until now with respect to the establishment of a temporary Indian day school at Alberni.

I may state, by way of comment, that it has been impossible to supply you with this information for the simple reason that a final decision was not reached until a few days ago.

You can readily appreciate that a great many letters had to be written to the Indian Agent and to the United Church authorities before the matter could be intelligently considered and a decision reached. The view was expressed at first that the enrolment might justify the establishment of two rooms and the employment of two teachers. The Agent, however, in his letter to the Department of July 14th, expressed the opinion that the enrolment would not justify the employment of more than one teacher. Mr. R. A. Hoey,

Dear Mr. Hoey:

You will remember that, when I was in your office, you spoke about the need of making changes in our teaching staff in British Columbia at Ucluelet and at Alberni. I took the matter up when I was there, and secured the co-operation of the officials in British Columbia.

I also interviewed Miss Pitts, and talked to her about the work and the desire to have a change made.

From the report submitted by Captain Barry - which you showed me - I gathered that there was every disposition on his part to have both Mr. Von Storch and Miss Pitts given an opportunity to make good somewhere else.

I beg, therefore, to nominate to your department as the teacher at Klemtu, Mr. Charles Von Storch.

For Ucluelet I beg to nominate Mr. E.B. Severson who has been our Missionary-Teacher at Fort Essington. I know that Captain Barry's report concerning Mr. Severson was not too enthusiastic, but at the same time I gathered that he might have another opportunity in a different type of community. That is why we are nominating him for Ucluelet.

For Campbell River I beg to nominate Miss Ketha Pitts who has been serving at Alberni.

With kindest regards, believe me,

Yours sincerely,

Geo. Dorey.

The Committee of the Privy Council have had before them a report, dated 7th January, 1938, from the Minister of Mines and Resources, stating:

That there are thirty-one (31) Indian children of school age on the Alberni Indian reserve, West Coast agency, province of British Columbia, for whom at present no educational facilities are provided;

That funds are available in the appropriation for the fiscal year 1937-38 —Vote No.169— for the establishment of a day school on the Alberni reserve.

The Minister, therefore, recommends that a day school be established on the Alberni reserve, West Coast agency, province of British Columbia, in accordance with the provisions of Section 9 (a) of the Indian Act, chapter 98, R.S.C. 1927, to be known as "The Alberni Indian Day School".

The Committee concur in the foregoing recommendation and submit the same for approval.

Clerk of the Privy Council.

The Honourable
The Minister of Mines and Resources.
Memorandum:

The DEPUTY MINISTER,-

I enclose herewith draft of Report to Council with reference to the establishment of the Alberni Indian Day School.

As you are aware, the main building at the Alberni Indian Residential School was destroyed by fire on February 21, 1937. As a result, approximately 31 children were left without school facilities.

One of the buildings formerly used in connection with the residential school was still available, and it was considered advisable to open a day school. The funds required for the teacher's salary in the maintenance of this day school are available in the current year's Appropriation.

Director.

Memorandum:

DEPUTY MINISTER

Alberni Indian Day School

In an effort to alleviate the crowded conditions at our residential schools, we are endeavouring to open as many day schools as possible. At the Alberni Residential School we have finished the classroom block and the Principal has indicated that he is now prepared to vacate the former day school building which was being used.

During a recent visit to Ottawa, Dr. Dorey of the United Church recommended the use of this day school again. Then the students of Opetchesahlt and Sheshahlt Indian Reserves can attend the day school rather than the residential school. This will enable us to place some 25 or 30 pupils from the more isolated reserves of Vancouver Island into the residential school.

Inspector of Schools Davey was requested to make a survey of the requirements in this area. You will find attached a copy of his report. Major MacKay, Inspector Davey and Indian Agent Garrard concur in recommending that the day school building be moved to a more central site, painted and generally put into condition for occupancy. They have secured a tender from a contractor, the Thompson Construction Company, for $1,232.25. A copy of this tender is attached.

I would recommend the acceptance of this tender, so that we may proceed to open another day school where it is sorely needed.

Encl.

Director.
MEMORANDUM

Re - School Survey - Alberni Day School -

When recently on Vancouver Island I made a survey of the requirements for the Sheshant and Opetchesah Reserve and have attached lists of the school age and pre-school age children, along with a summary showing the total possible enrolments for each of the next seven years.

Requirements:

A two-room school is required at the present time, and the rate of increase indicates that three rooms will be needed within ten years. However the old one room class-room building at the Alberni Residential School will not be used by the Residential School in the 1947-48 term. This would serve temporarily until it is possible to secure other accommodation, if the children of six years of age are excluded. This would give a maximum enrolment for the 1947-48 term of 39. If this building is used it should be moved on to the Sheshant Reserve to be away from the Residential School. It would be difficult to move it to the Opetchesah Reserve as the bridge across the Somas River is too narrow to take the building, and as the river banks are very steep. At any rate twice as many pupils would attend from the Sheshant Reserve as from the Opetchesah Reserve. This one room school would serve for two or three years, and would give a clear picture of the actual requirements.

Site:

There is an excellent site to the north of the Sheshant village playground. This is well located with respect to the population on this reserve, and has the advantage of an already prepared playground. The distance from this site to the farthest home on the Opetchesah Reserve
is 1.8 miles and 1.5 miles to the closest home. The Alberni School Board transports pupils who live over three miles, and generally in this Province pupils living over two miles from the school are carried by bus. In this particular case the road which the pupils will have to travel carried heavy traffic and has no sidewalk. If the local bus schedule is improved it will be possible to carry the twelve pupils from the Opetchesht Reserve to the border of the Sheshaht Reserve for 5¢ a head for each trip.

I suggest that Mr. Indian Agent Garrard be asked to report on the availability of this proposed site, and the cost of moving the building. If these two factors present no difficulty, I shall recommend the establishment of the Day School on the Sheshaht Reserve, and the temporary use of the old classroom building.

R. F. Davey,
Inspector of Indian Schools.

P.S. The Principal of the Alberni Residential School has been consulted and agrees to this use of the building.

Re - Alberni Indian Day School -

I enclose herewith Inspector Davey's memorandum of the 28th ult., reviewing the educational requirements of the Opetchesahlt and Sheshahlt Indian Reserves of the West Coast Agency, indicating that while a two roomed school would be required to provide for the present estimated enrolment, and a three roomed building within the next few years, a one room school, for the present, would enable us to better determine our future requirements. He recommends that the old day school located on the Alberni Residential School property, which has been in use by them since fire destroyed the classroom shortly after its construction, could be moved to a suitable location on the adjoining Sheshahlt Reserve for this purpose. He estimates that about two-thirds of the pupils would be from Sheshahlt Reserve, and one third from Opetchesahlt Reserve, which is about 1½ miles distant.

Mr. Indian Agent Garrard has secured the enclosed quotation for $1,232.25 from a contractor, Mr. Thompson, for clearing the new site, moving building to it on new footings, painting exterior and interior and generally putting it in condition for occupation, which appears quite reasonable under present conditions. He also provides for a circulatory heater at a cost of $85.95, a total of $1,309.20. Also forty new desks will be required, on which quotations will be secured, if you approve of the opening of this school.

If it is found necessary to transport the Opetchesahlt children to and from the school, this will cost, at the

Re: Alberni Indian Day School

With reference to Mr. Henry's letter of Dec. 27th (file 159-21-5 T.T.), and communication from the Manager of the Canadian Bank of Commerce at Port Alberni regarding assignment of money accruing to "R. E. T. Thompson" in connection with the removal and repair of the above mentioned day school building, the assignment form is returned herewith.

With respect to the statement enclosed with the assignment, the extra amount of $42.00 mentioned has nothing to do with R. Thompson's contract, being composed of an amount of $40.00 charged for levelling off the site where the day school was originally situated, a voucher for which has already been forwarded to the Department, and an amount of $2.00 for levelling the grounds around the Neshaht Band Community Hall. Payment of this latter amount has been requested by the Band from Band funds, which will be the subject of a separate communication. The item "remaining on painting - $38.00" does not enter the picture being included in the contract price, but apparently was shown separately for the reason that the painting was not completed at the time the statement was prepared, but according to advice received from R. Indian Agent Gerrard has now been completed in accordance with the contract.

Re: Education - Alberni Residential School and Day Schools

The writer has visited Alberni Residential School on two occasions while at the West Coast Agency and during both visits the subject of classroom accommodation was discussed at length with the Principal, Mr. Caldwell. It will be recalled that while a four room block was built in recent years two additional classrooms of a temporary nature have had to be added to prevent overcrowding.

In addition to the lack of classroom accommodation referred to, a serious problem of classroom facilities exists on the Indian Reserves immediately adjacent to the Residential school where an old one-room school, at present in use, is entirely inadequate for the pupilage on the Reserves. I attach hereto a memorandum from Mr. Davey, our School Inspector, dated September 29th, in which he submits a proposition to adequately care for the educational requirements at the Residential school and adjoining Reserves.

During Dr. Dorey's recent visit to Vancouver a meeting was arranged at this office with Dr. Dorey, Mr. Caldwell, Mr. Davey and the writer to discuss various phases of our school administration at the Residential School. Mr. Davey's memorandum, with which I fully concur, was touched upon and I gather that Dr. Dorey and Mr. Caldwell feel that the erection of an additional four room block catering to the Residential school pupils and the Indian Reserve Day school pupils on a full day basis and under the jurisdiction of this Branch would be a decidedly forward step and one leading to an adequate and worthwhile educational program.
I strongly recommend the erection of this additional four-room block to be operated under the jurisdiction of this Branch by adding to the existing recently built four-room block at the Residential School.

In addition to the above subject and recommendation, I attach hereto a self-explanatory memorandum from Mr. Davey, dated September 1st, covering the problem of the ever increasing number of pupils from Indian Day schools and Residential schools who desire to go forward to higher education. You will note from this memorandum that Provincial high school and technical school courses are available at present and will be to an even greater extent in the future at Alberni where we have always enjoyed excellent cooperation from the local High School Board. It seems logical that we should take advantage of entering possibly up to forty pupils from our Residential school and surrounding Indian Reserves where higher education is not available and this could readily be reached by arrangements with the Alberni School Board and by the erection of two moderate, separate dwellings upon the Residential school property providing dormitory space (one for boys and one for girls) for up to twenty pupils each, where the pupils could reside and be under the direct supervision of the Residential school Principal after school hours. The suggested location is ideal from, I think, every point of view for such a plan and with the pupils living in pleasant surroundings with regular evening study periods and supervised recreational activities at the Residential school and in Alberni it is my opinion that such an arrangement would prove successful and go a long way towards the desired assimilation of the pupils concerned.

W.S. Arneil,
Indian Commissioner for B.C.

MEMORANDUM

To: The Indian Commissioner for B.C.

From: The District School Inspector.

Re: Alberni Day and Residential Schools.

The large enrolment at the Alberni Day School makes it imperative that an addition be constructed to accommodate one more classroom at this school. At the same time the Residential School, which is some 200 yards from the Day School, has a four-room classroom block to accommodate approximately 235 pupils. In addition to the four classrooms two temporary rooms have been provided in the basement to relieve the overcrowding in the four regular classrooms. It would seem logical therefore that a single unit be constructed to relieve the serious overcrowding in the Day School and at the same time provide for accommodation to enable all pupils at the Residential School to attend the classroom on a full-time basis. The authorized enrolment at the residential school is 225 pupils but normally carries in the neighbourhood of 235 and the anticipated enrolment for the current academic year at the Day School is 48. In order to provide for this number of pupils and the anticipated increase in the next five years at least eight classrooms should be available. There are four classrooms at the Residential School which we can continue to use. The Day School building is an old structure formerly used at the old Alberni Residential School, which has been temporarily fixed up to serve the Opetchisahlt and Seshahlt Reserves. I suggest that the solution for this problem is to construct a four-classroom block on the Residential School grounds adjacent to the present building and operate the eight classrooms thus provided as a day school to which the pupils of the Residential
School would attend. This proposal is made not only because of the need for increased classroom facilities, which is obvious from the foregoing figures, but also because of the present financial condition of the Alberni Residential School as shown in the recent audit. It will be noted from this that the school has a very heavy bank overdraft and its financial position is most precarious. If this condition is allowed to continue we will undoubtedly be faced with the rapid deterioration of the school because it will be unable to pay salaries sufficiently high to secure a competent staff. The operation of the eight classrooms as a day school would bring all the teachers under the provisions of the day school salary schedule and also make the teaching positions more attractive by enabling teachers to be classified as Civil Servants for salary purposes, and probably give some relief to the financial problems of the Residential School.

I recommend the separation of the normal classroom work from the operation of the Residential School so that we would have at this point an eight room day school to which children in residence at the Residential School will attend as day pupils. The teachers employed at this school would be subject to the regulations that apply to day school teachers.

In addition to the classroom block accommodation will have to be provided by way of a teacherage for four teachers.

With regard to the per capita grant, I would suggest that for the first year of operation there should be no reduction because it would appear that with the full time attendance of senior pupils in the classroom additional staff will be required in the residence and it is possible that the saving of expenditure by the residential School will not be great enough to put the finances on a firm basis. At the end of the year's operation an audit will indicate the grant which would be suitable for the operation of the residence.

R.F. Davey,
Inspector of Indian Schools in B.C.
MEMORANDUM

September 1, 1948.

To: The Indian Commissioner of B.C.

From: The District Inspector of Indian Schools.

Re: Hostel for High School Pupils.

There is an increasing number of pupils in our Indian Day Schools reaching the level of High School, and this is creating a problem of finding accommodation in the white communities where these pupils may receive High School instruction. The greatest number of these pupils are members of bands residing on the coast and are of Protestant affiliation.

With this in mind, a possible location for such a hostel would appear to be at the Alberni Residential School. This school already has about a dozen pupils in attendance at the local High School and the results have been good. The Alberni Provincial School Board has an extensive building programme under way which includes a large, modern high school which will include a comprehensive vocational training programme, including industrial arts, home economics, and business courses.

A second solution would be to establish a hostel in Vancouver, or one of the adjoining municipalities. Such a location would have several advantages over the Alberni suggestion. It would be easier for the Vancouver schools to absorb a large group of Indian pupils. A wider variety of opportunities for vocational instruction are offered both in the large Technical School already established and a second similar school now under construction, and in the large number of private institutions offering specialized instruction. However, the Vancouver location...
has the serious handicap of the size of the city, which makes
the problem of adequate supervision extremely difficult.
Pupils residing in Vancouver are likely to be subject to many
distractions and to the influence of certain undesirable
elements always more prevalent in larger centres. This refers,
in particular, to teen age girls.

The securing of someone capable and sufficiently
interested to operate such an institution might present con-
siderable difficulty. Although, for the above reasons, I
favour the establishment of a hostel at Alberni under the
direction of the principal of the residential School, I
suggest that it is practical to try, on a small scale, such
an experiment at both points. These establishments should be
of the cottage type along the lines of that in operation at
the Fairbridge Farm School. A beginning could be made with
the erection of a building at Alberni and Vancouver capable
of handling ten to fourteen pupils at each point and expanded
where warranted.

Before going any further, with these suggestions,
I feel that it would be wise to secure the Department's reaction
to the proposal.

R.F. Davey,
District Inspector of Indian
Schools.

Re: Alberni Day School

The Sheshahlt Community Hall was used last year as a school classroom at the above-mentioned school. But, as this is an enormous room far beyond the requirements of the class and most difficult to heat, it is felt that this year it would be preferable to carry on classes in the entrance hall of the building, which is a room of most suitable size.

Supt. Garrard advises that the cost of converting this room for school use will be possibly $255.00, and I would recommend that funds to this extent be made available. Approximately $60.00 of the amount is required for labour and I would ask that an accountable advance of this amount be send to Mr. Garrard.

W.S. Arneil

Dear Sir:

In reply to your letter of September 24th last with reference to a proposed agreement with your Department for payment of a share of the capital costs of Gill School, I am directed to advise you that the contract for the construction of this school has been awarded to Port Alberni Home Builders Limited for the sum of $143,523.00.

Re: Disposal Alberni Indian Day School

With reference to your letter dated June 19th, with regard to the disposal of the above mentioned buildings to the Sheshant Band of Indians.

To begin with, this building was never a Day School until it was moved off the Residential School grounds on to the Indian Reserve. From 1910 - 1927 this building was used as a detached class-room for the resident pupils. The Principal of the Residential school at the time was Mr. H. B. Currie, a resident from Alberni. Mr. Currie erected the Day School in 1911. It was on a cement wall, concrete floor with the basement used as a pupils playroom. The approximate cost of this building at that time was $1000.00.

In the early days of Indian Education the property and buildings were erected by the Churches. This Day School was built with Presbyterian Church money.

The Residential School was destroyed by fire on June 3, 1917. The new Residential school was constructed by this Department in 1920-21. In the meantime from 1927 until completion of the new school, classes were carried on in the Day School. This new Residential school was also destroyed by fire during Rev. Pitts Principalship, about 1934 or 1935. The Day school was again absorbing many children who attended the Residential School for a time.

The Presbyterian work in the Day School ceased when Church union was consumated, at which time it passed over to the United Church in 1925.
W. S. Arneil:

From 1925 - 1950 Departmental funds were used for repairs and upkeep to the Day School with no specific alterations made to the building itself.

In 1950 the Day School ceased to function as a classroom when the new Gill Elementary school opened at the Fall term with all local Indian children attending a Public school for the first time.

We are pleased to advise that the Indian children have adjusted themselves very satisfactorily to their new environment, and on the average are keeping up with the white children in their studies. We can foresee no future use of the old building as a classroom again. The local bands are extremely satisfied with the present school arrangements, and mark it as a great advancement in Indian Education.

The present worth of the Day School is considered to be approximately $400.00

We have been approached by the Sheshahlt Council regarding the possibilities of acquiring possession of the Alberni Indian Day School, and to be declared property of the band. This building, located on reserve No. 1, ceased to function as a school about three years ago, at which time the children proceeded to attend the new Gill Elementary Public school located in the Alberni district. Since then the school building has been occupied by the Sheshahlt and Opetchesault Homemaker's club and for Church services conducted under the auspices of the United Church of Alberni.

Dear Doctor Dorey:

Re: Alberni Indian Day School Building

About 1948, following the completion of the first of the two four-classroom blocks now in use at the Alberni Residential School, the old building formerly used as a classroom at the Alberni Residential School when it operated under Presbyterian auspices, was moved to the Sheshaht Reserve which joins the residential school property, and was renovated to serve that reserve as a day school. Subsequently, arrangements were made for the admission of the children of this reserve to the Gill Provincial Elementary School. Since 1950 it has been used for church services and to serve as a meeting place for the Homemakers' Club.

I am now informed that the Sheshaht Band wish to acquire this building in order that it may be set aside for the exclusive use of the church. If the Band is successful, they propose to name it the "Sheshaht United Church". I presume that the clergyman doing the missionary work on the Sheshaht Reserve is fully aware of the circumstances, and you may wish to contact him concerning this matter.

The department is prepared to turn this building over to the Band for the use indicated above. However, the church, as well as the department, appears to have an interest in the building, and before making any definite commitment I would appreciate having your comments as to whether or not the proposal in connection with this building meets with your approval.

Yours sincerely,

Philip Phelan,

On June 23rd 1930 I held a largely attended Meeting at the Indian Village of Moricetown on the Moricetown Indian Reserve. Two of the main subjects at the Meeting were the desire of the Moricetown Indians to have a Residential School built at Moricetown. Many of the Indians voiced their objections to sending their children to the Indian Residential School at Lejac B.C. I suggested a Day School, but they were strongly in favour of a Residential School, stating that a large number of children could be drawn from the Fort Babine, Hagwilget and Moricetown Reserves sufficient to authorize the building of a suitable School.

Knowing that the Rev Father Coccola, Principal of the Lejac Indian Residential School would be in Moricetown on or about the 12th of July 1930, I delayed this Report pending an interview with the Rev Father Coccola.

On July 12th 1930, I met the Rev Fathers Coccola and Godfrey at Moricetown, and explained to them the desire of the Moricetown Indians regarding a Residential School at Moricetown. The Rev Father Coccola informed me that he had been approached by the Indians on the subject; he stated to me that the proposition would not be feasible at the present time. Father Godfrey agreed with Father Coccola on the matter.

No doubt a Indian Residential School at Moricetown would be a valuable asset to the Moricetown, Hagwilget and Fort Babine Indians, but the cost of same would be considerable, and I am of opinion there is not sufficient suitable agricultural land, either in the Moricetown Reserve or adjacent for such a purpose.

Hagwilget and Fort Babine Indian Reserves have Indian Day Schools, and both are largely attended by the Indian Children.

The Secretary
Department of Indian Affairs
Ottawa, Ont

Your obedient servant,
G.J. Mortimer
Indian Agent

Re Indian Day School at Moricetown Indian Reserve

Sir,

I am enclosing herewith a letter received today from David Francis, Chief of the Moricetown Band. Before I pass any comments on an Indian Day School at Moricetown, may I be permitted to draw your attention to the attitude of the Moricetown & Hagwilget Indians towards the Fraser Lake Indian Residential School? They simply refuse to send their children there, and when I asked them to state their reasons, they set forth all kinds of complaints etc., many of them very unreasonable.

Dealing with the matter regarding an Indian Day School at Moricetown, I have made careful inquiries re same, and am firmly of opinion that the Rev Fathers Coccolia and Godfrey are doing their best under the circumstances. I find there are in the neighborhood of twenty children in and around Moricetown of school age who would benefit by an Indian Day School at that point.

Both Fathers Coccolia and Godfrey object to any Indian Day School at Moricetown, stating that the Fraser Lake Indian Residential School is for that purpose, and therefore the Hagwilget Indian Children must go there.

I feel that this matter requires careful consideration and tact; I therefore kindly solicit your advice in the matter.

The Secretary
Department of Indian Affairs
Ottawa, Ont.

Your obedient Servant

G.C. Mortimer

Dear Sir:

I beg to submit herewith my report upon the Babine Agency.

General:

In connection with school matters, Mr. Mortimer informs me that there are about 40 children at Old Fort Babine (Nedoots 11 and 13) and adjoining Reserves, at Halifax (Todinlay 15, etc.) that should be in school. There is no room at Le Jac (Fraser Lake School) and I expect that this school will have to be added to. I was also spoken to by the Anglican Missionary at Hazelton about a residential school there. A school for Protestant children is being asked for on the Northern Coast. This has, I understand been already mooted, but the choice of its locality seems a somewhat controversial point. Personally I think Prince Rupert, owing to its central position, easy transportation access, power on the spot also water. Of course, some distance out of Prince Rupert along the road where these things are. However, against this is the fact that there would be no farming attached though where that could be procured other than Hazelton, I do not know.

Geo. S. Pragnell,
Inspector of Indian Agencies.

Sir,

In reply to your letter No 151-0-1 dated October 2nd 1930, I respectfully beg to state that on October 17th I attended another meeting of the Moricetown Indians, at an Indian Day School at that point.

I must say that the Moricetown Indians are very anxious to get an Indian Day School; at the meeting about fifteen children of school age accompanied by their parents were in attendance, not one of these children ever attended a school, and their ages ran from six to seventeen years of age. I have only the word of David Tyee the Chief and members of the band, that from fifteen to twenty children would attend such school.

Previous to the meeting I had an interview with the Rev Father Godfrey and asked him to attend the meeting with me, this he promised to do, but when the meeting was called through some reason Father Godfrey was unable to do so.

Regarding Para-2 of my letter to you No MI-5-247 dated September 23rd 1930, what I mean to infer is, that both Fathers Coccola and Godfrey are doing their best to get the Moricetown Indians to send their children to the Fraser Lake Residential School. I have no hesitation in saying that both Fathers Coccola and Godfrey strongly object to an Indian Day School at Moricetown.

From personal observations I am of opinion that an Indian Day School would be an asset to the Moricetown Reserve, since taking over the Babine Agency a very friendly feeling has existed between Fathers Coccola & Godfrey and myself, on several occasions I have received friendly advice from both those gentlemen on affairs pertaining to the Indians of the Babine Lake Reserves, and therefore would that the Department of Indian Affairs should guide me in dealing with this matter.

The Secretary
Department of Indian Affairs
Ottawa, Ont.

Your obedient servant

Dear Sir:

I beg to forward to your Office the enclosed signatures of Indians from Reserves 1 and 2 at Moricetown B.C., petitioning hereby for an Indian Day School at Moricetown. Attached to their signatures is a list of the supposed children who are of School age; I am not in a position to ascertain whether the figures given are true; Father Dream, the missionary in charge, tells me that the children of School age at Moricetown would be around 30, if all were present.

I mentioned the said petition to Inspector Barry of Victoria upon his last visit here some two weeks ago; he said that he would be willing to investigate the conditions of the Indians of Moricetown regarding a proposed day School, provided he would get instructions to that effect from the Department.

I beg your Department, therefore, to take the demand of these Indians into consideration, especially in view of the fact that a day school at Moricetown would not interfere with our work at Lejac; so far very few children from that district have come to our boarding School, and the reserves surrounding Lejac can amply provide the Residential School here with the amount of children we are allowed to receive.

INSPECTOR'S SURVEY REPORT ON MORICETOWN INDIAN VILLAGE

Roman Catholic Church Babine Agency

Purpose of Survey:

This survey was undertaken, on the instructions of the Indian Affairs Branch, with a view to determine the necessity for the establishment of an Indian Day School at Moricetown, and if such a school should be found to be necessary to locate a proper site for the proposed school.

State of Survey:

On May 22nd 1937, accompanied by the Acting Indian Agent of the Babine Agency, Mr. Mallinson, I made a very thorough inspection of the Moricetown Indian Village. Many of the Indians were interviewed and an inspection made of the larger houses.

Map:

A very rough sketch map or plan of the village was made, and from this the attached ROUGH SKETCH MAP was drawn. No map was available which could copy and the work had to be done on the spot in a few minutes. I must ask the kind consideration of all the officials of the Indian Affairs Branch who may read this report, for it is a very rough map indeed which is attached and it is only forwarded in the belief that any map is better than no map.

Attitude of Indians:

The Indians of Moricetown were not all seen as quite a number were away from the village. The twenty or so seen were all very emphatic in their requests for an Indian Day School. They told me that they had asked for several years for a school, and in answer to my question told me that certainly they would send their children to school regularly.

Were a school to be erected here, and the local Indians given some of the work under the direct supervision of a "white" carpenter, they would get in logs if necessary and work well, I am certain.

The Indians were very respectful and well mannered. They quite understood that I could not promise them a school, and were satisfied when I told them before leaving that I should certainly recommend the establishment of a school in Moricetown, but that I did not believe there were sufficient funds to build a school at present. I told them that the numbers attending would decide the question of whether a school should be built later. There are a number of HALLS available and the Indians all seemed anxious to have one or another of these selected. I was led to understand that the necessary work would be done, on the one selected, by the owner and the actual building rented to the Indian Affairs Branch in a state of good repair. I did not of course promise that any building would be rented.

The general attitude of the Indians was far better than in many of the villages where we have had a school for years. Mr. Mallinson did most of the actual talking to the Indians, but I talked to them myself to make perfectly certain that they did in fact want a school very badly. The children whom I saw said they wanted to come to school. Only one or two had been at any school ever. I saw one child from Le Jac.

Indian Affairs. (RG 10, Volume 6420, file 861-1, part 1)
Numbers of Children Available:

The Acting Indian Agent, Mr. McMillinon, at my request has been good enough to prepare several pages of detailed information as to the actual children available and their ages, the names and ages of those children who are at present under school age but who would of course later be available. These pages are now incorporated in my report for the information of the Director of Welfare and Training.

Names of parents are given, and when necessary the distances from the building which I suggest should be used as a school to the child's home is also given.

It will be seen that there are a large number of children of school age available for school now, and quite a number of children of under school age who will replace those leaving at the age of fifteen or sixteen years.

What is much more important is the fact that if the school be located in Moricetown a number of Indians at present living in other villages, Smithers, Telkwa, etc., are said to be determined to return to Moricetown.

Smithers, Telkwa, etc., are small towns and not Indian villages, and it will be to the advantage of the Indians to get them back on the Indian reserves.

There are a number of Indians living at TWO MILE, which is, as the name would imply, just about two miles north of Moricetown. These Indians still have their children walk daily to Moricetown to attend school. A school located near the mile post on the Hazelton to Smithers road which reads Hazelton 28 miles Smithers 31 miles might be considered the central point. It would be at a point a little to the north of my sketch map. It should be remembered that it is quite possible that some children will walk from Hudson Bay a place about three miles south east of Moricetown, and this has been taken into consideration in locating the best place for an Indian school.

While the numbers given to me by Mr. McMillinon are accurate and may be relied on by the Indian Affairs Branch I certainly consider that the proposed school should be furnished with equipment for at least forty children. This will be necessary to take care of the children returning from the towns mentioned above in addition to those now living on the local Indian Reserves.

Part of the time given to the survey was taken up in checking the names and ages of the Indian children, so that the attached lists might be as complete as possible.

I would therefore recommend that an Indian Day School to accommodate at least forty children of ages from six years to sixteen be established at Moricetown to open on September 1st 1937.
Buildings:

There are a number of Halls as they are called available. I do not recommend the building of an Indian school at the present time.

It is possible that later on a large Day School with accommodation on one end for a teachers' residence may be necessary, but at present this is not so, and a rented building will be most satisfactory here.

There are three Halls available. These are marked "A", "B" and "D" on the attached map.

There are also three possible places where a teacher might live. These are marked "E", "F" and "G" on the map.

"B" Hall

This Hall belongs to Peter Michell (Indian). It was built in 1923. It is of frame construction. The logs on which it rests are set on concrete blocks. The outside is F. and G. weather boarding. While the floor is satisfactory, the upstairs is not finished and the whole of the inside needs to be lined. The construction is not very good. The location is not a good one for a school as there are houses quite near and there is no available space for a playground. The building is about 36 feet by 21 feet. I do not consider that this building is in any way suitable as a school.

"D" Hall

This Hall together with the house marked "E" might do well enough for a school and a teacher's home. They are located in about two acres of partly cleared land fronting on the main road, which is not a good point.

The Hall is of log construction supported on cedar posts and logs. It is about 36 feet by 24 feet. It is not lined. It has a ship lap floor. The upstairs is not yet finished and there is no stairway at present.

Much work would be necessary on this building but the owner says he is willing to finish it if it were chosen as the school. It was built in 1934.

The location is in a place which could make a playground if it were fenced from the main road. The owner is Arthur Michell and this man is quite equal to carrying out his promises. He is an Indian who works in the supplying of poles to some of Mr. Hanson's camps, and is quite well off. He tells me that he would put up a fence and make this and the house marked "E" suitable for a school and teacher's home.

He told me he would want a rent of $12.00 a month for the two places and the surrounding ground, and he split this into $8.00 for the Hall and $4.00 for the little frame house "E".

The house "E" has a room downstairs and one upstairs. It is not very well constructed of ship lap. The windows do not fit. It is 15 feet by 25 feet and is the poorest of the three places located as possible teacher's residences. The location near the Church and Priest's house is good. There is back part of the cleared land around the Hall "D" is said to flood in the Spring. It lies low. The cars passing on the main road make this a dusty place.

I do not think the Hall "D" and the house "E" should be chosen for a school and teacher's residence unless we could not obtain any other place at a suitable rent.
Buildings Continued:

"A" Hall. This Hall is the property of Tyee Lake David who lives at Telkwa. It is of frame construction with rough weather boarding outside and cedar ship lap lining inside. It has a good floor at present used as a dance hall. The upstairs is poor and has a lot of old beds and mattresses etc., in it now.

The building is about 35 feet by 25 feet. The supports of the upstairs are too weak and some three strong uprights should be placed to take the weight of the central beam. There are six windows, two on each of three sides. This is a poor plan but might do for the present.

The location is splendid as may be seen from the sketch map attached.

This building is on rather higher land than the remainder of the village. It is located in about an acre away from the rest of the village and is surrounded by short grass and a few small trees. This would make a very nice little playground.

There is a well at the back of the building. I found it to be dry, or at least with some snow in it. It seemed about 20 feet deep and about 4½ wide. It is said to go to rock.

Near this "A" Hall there is a small one room log cottage marked "C" on the map. It belongs to David Dennis who does not live there, and would I believe rent it. The little house is very well built and would be warm. It is about 16 feet by 24 feet. It would be worth about $4.00 a month for the twelve months of the year.

It is well located from a healthful point of view and near the "A" Hall which I certainly think would make a good school house.

The "A" Hall would be worth around $12.00 per month for the twelve months of the year.

The remaining possible teacher's cottage is that marked "F" and belongs to Tom Michell. It is nearly half a mile from the "A" Hall, is about 15 feet by 16 feet, and is built of logs with an upstairs room.

This "F" cottage is fairly well built and would suit a married couple.

Recommendation on Buildings:

I would recommend that the "A" Hall and the "C" cottage be rented if the sums asked are not greatly in excess of the valuation I have made above, the "A" Hall to be converted into the proposed Moricetown Indian Day School and the "C" Cottage used by the teacher if single.

Equipment:

I shall be very glad to help the Acting Indian Agent with a list of necessary equipment should the Indian Affairs Branch decide to establish this school as recommended. At least forty SINGLE CROWN SCHOOL DESKS will be required, Asbestoslate Boards and a teacher's Table and Chair. I do not consider it necessary to list here such things as a simple flag pole and Union Jack which are most necessary in any Indian school. On request from Ottawa I shall do my best to help the local Indian Agent in the establishment of this school.

General Remarks:

I do not think I need add anything to what has been reported above.

I believe that the need for an Indian Day School has been established, and the location selected of the Hall marked "A" a very good one indeed for such a school.

I asked the Indians what kind of teacher they wanted if they got a school. I was told by them that they left that to the Roman Catholic Church and the Inspector.

May I recommend in closing that a very experienced teacher be chosen for this new school, if it is decided to establish one here. Again I may say that I shall be glad to assist in the selection of the best candidate from several suggested by the Catholic Church authorities, or in any other way that the Indian Affairs Branch may require. I am anxious that no young man with little experience or without a B.C. Certificate be selected as teacher.

The Indian parents and children are alike eager for a school, and any mistake in the selection of the first teacher here would ruin the good feeling now being shown in the village.

It should be remembered that we have a Field Matron, Mrs Edith Maclean on this Indian Reserve. Mrs. Maclean lives some miles away from Moricetown. She tells me that the Indian parents are buying new clothes for their children in anticipation of there being a school at Moricetown in September.

Dear Major MacKay:

I am forwarding herewith my Survey Report on Moricetown, in the Babine Agency. A very rough sketch map is attached to make parts of my report clear to the Indian Affairs Branch. This, I am afraid, is a very rough map indeed, but it is the best I could do with the few materials at hand.

The whole report is made at the request of the Indian Affairs Branch in Ottawa. I do not appear to have the number of the letter of instruction here, and I would ask to quote it when forwarding my report to Ottawa.

In gathering material and facts for the report I was helped greatly by the Acting Indian Agent, Mr. Mallinson, who accompanied me to Moricetown on May 22nd last. Transportation was provided by the R.C.M.P. stationed in Hazelton.

I have no hesitation in recommending the establishment of an Indian Day School at Moricetown, and would recommend that if the necessary funds can be found the school be opened next September.

Yours very truly,

Gerald H. Barry,
Inspector of Indian Schools, B.C.

Dear Sir:

I beg to forward herewith the survey report by Capt. G. H. Barry, Inspector of Indian Schools for B.C., on Moricetown, in the Babine Agency. This report was made at the request of the Department.

It will be noted Capt. Barry does not recommend the construction of a new school at this time at Moricetown, but that a Day School be established to open on September 1st of this year and that the available accommodation marked A and C on the accompanying sketch be approved to be used for the school and teacher's residence, respectively. From the description given by Inspector Barry on the present condition of the hall marked "A", some improvements of an inexpensive character should be made prior to the opening of the school, among them, additional uprights to support the upstairs section of the building. It may also be necessary to make some minor repairs to the doors and windows. The floors would appear to be in good condition.

There is evidently real need for an Indian Day School at Moricetown, and I am convinced it would be a definite step forward to approve of the recommendations made by Capt. Barry in this matter.

Yours faithfully,

D. M. MacKay,
Indian Commissioner for B.C.

MEMORANDUM:

The Deputy Minister.

For several years past, the Department has been urged to establish a day school on the Moricetown Reserve, Babine Indian Agency, Northern British Columbia. This request was renewed this year and Inspector Barry was instructed to make a survey of the situation.

Under cover of a letter dated June 8th, 1937, Commissioner McKay forwards Mr. Barry's report. This shows that there are approximately seventy (70) children of school age, none of whom have had the advantage of any education. The Indians themselves are extremely anxious for the establishment of a school.

Inspector Barry strongly recommends that a school be opened on September 1st and Indian Commissioner McKay concurs in this recommendation.

It will not be necessary to erect a building, as a vacant hall on the reserve can be rented at a very reasonable cost.

The funds required for incidental expenses in connection with the establishment of the school and paying rent, etc., and for the salary of the teacher, can be provided from the Appropriation for Indian Education. I feel that a school should be opened at Moricetown and would appreciate having your concurrence. In this event, it will be necessary, in view of the requirements of Section 9 (a) of the Indian Act, to secure an Order-in-Council. I enclose the necessary Memorandum to Council.

The Department is, also, in receipt of a letter from Mr. Olef Hansen, M. P., in which he recommends the appointment of Miss Orrice B. Sargent as teacher of the Moricetown Indian Day School, if it is established.

Acting Director.

Dear Sir:

As provided by Section 9 (a) of the Indian Act, authority has now been secured by Order-in-Council for the establishment of a day school on the Noricetown Reserve.

You may therefore make arrangements for the opening of this school on January 3, 1938.

The Department approves the appointment of Miss O.B. Sargent, whom you stated in your letter of June 16th was recommended by Mr. Olaf Hanson, M.P., and Right Reverend Bishop Bunoz, O.M.I. She will be allowed salary at the rate of $1,000 a year. This is paid on the basis of ten teaching months in the academic year. I enclose staff questionnaire, which you should have her complete and return to the Department.

In your letter of June 8, 1937,(15-49154) you enclosed Inspector Barry's report on the Noricetown Reserve. On page 4 of this report Inspector Barry suggested the renting of "A" hall from Tyee Lake David at a rental of $12.00 a month, also the rental of a log cottage owned by an Indian named David Dennis, who stated that this could be secured for $4.00 per month for teachers residence. You may arrange for the rental of these two buildings from January 1st next.

Inspector Barry further stated that 40 single crown desks would be required, also a teacher's table and chair. You may arrange for the purchase of these.
You may also secure any other necessary equipment that you consider required for either the school or the teacher's residence, but the cost of everything purchased should be kept to the lowest possible point. Inspector Barry should forward a requisition for the books, stationery, etc., that he considers should be supplied. This requisition should also include the blackboard and the length and width of this should be stated so that an order may be placed with the Government stationery office.

Dear Sir:

On the authority contained in the second paragraph of Departmental letter 151-22-1 of the 18th instant I have accepted as teacher of the Moricetown Indian day school for the academic year 1939-40 Mr. George W. Cleveland, nominated by His Excellency Bishop Bunoz, O.M.I.

Mr. Cleveland's qualifications were set out in a letter from Inspector Barry dated August 3rd forwarded to you with my 15/1/727 of August 4th.

In brief he is a married man and aged 29. He has not had Normal School training but states that he passed the Ontario Senior Matriculation and taught manual training to unemployed youths in Manitoba. He is a Catholic and is willing to follow the advice of our Inspector of Schools. Mr. Cleveland has stated his willingness to take Provincial Summer School or Normal School courses later as advised by Captain Barry.

While our Inspector of Schools is willing to recommend the appointment of Mr. Cleveland as teacher of the Moricetown Indian day school, he considers that as this man has no Normal School training he should be appointed for only one year in the first instance, and with this viewpoint I am in agreement.

The last teacher at Moricetown, Miss Sargent, was paid at the rate of $100.00 per teaching month though she had no particular qualifications for this work. The school is in a rather out of the way place and there is no furniture in the addition to the Indian hall, rented as a school, which is being used as a teacher's residence. Under the circumstances, and as it may be necessary for Mr. Cleveland to make arrangements for renting another house to accommodate his wife and children, I do not consider the above mentioned salary excessive.

I should be glad to have the Department's confirmation of the action taken in due course, but as the time is so short Mr. Cleveland is being instructed to open school at Moricetown at the beginning of the academic year. He has been supplied with a copy of questionnaire C150-52. A copy of this letter has also been forwarded to His Excellency Bishop Bunoz md to the acting Indian Agent at Hazelton.

Yours faithfully,

Dear Major MacKay:

I have read the correspondence to date with regard to the Indian day schools at Moricetown and Old Fort Babine, in the Babine Agency, and the letters from His Excellency Bishop Bunoz, O.M.I. in connection with these schools.

This morning I visited the officials of the Catholic Church here in Vancouver in an attempt to discover any suitable Catholic candidates with B.C. certificates for the above mentioned schools. I have also had interviews with two or three teachers.

In general I may say that there exists a very great shortage of teachers with good qualifications, so that male teachers with B.C. certificates are almost impossible to find. For the above named schools we need married teachers and I am quite unable to find any married Catholic with a B.C. certificate.

In the case of the Moricetown vacancy I wish to put forward for the information of His Excellency Bishop Bunoz the below mentioned candidate:

GEORGE W. CLEVELAND - Age 29, Married Mary (Crawford) age 26; the two children are 5 and 2 years of age. Mr. Cleveland has Senior Matriculation standing in Ontario. He has taught Manual Training to unemployed Manitoba youths. His wife is a teacher of music. Mr. Cleveland is in good health and has a very good personality. He much wishes to be a teacher and would later when he has earned a little money take courses at the Provincial Summer school and Normal school. He is willing to do what he is told and to follow my suggestions. I consider him a much better candidate than even the last teacher at Moricetown on whose work I reported favourably.

Mr. Cleveland is of course a Catholic and is recommended by the Catholic Church authorities of the Archdiocese of Vancouver. I have instructed him to write direct to His Excellency Bishop Bunoz in the hope that the Bishop might give him the Moricetown nomination. I am prepared to recommend Mr. Cleveland for such a position, and should he obtain the Bishop's nomination and the Department's appointment I shall give him several hours' instruction in this office previous to his departure for the school.

Yours very truly,

Gerald H. Barry.

Dear Sir:

Mr. Indian Agent Mallinson, Babine Agency, informs me that a white man, Mr. Thistle, foreman of the Canadian National Railway at Moricetown, is very anxious that permission might be given for three of his children to attend the Moricetown Indian Day School during the coming academic year.

This matter has been discussed with Captain Barry, inspector of Indian Schools, and the matter has also been brought to the attention of the Provincial Department of Education in Victoria, who state that that Department cannot agree to pay any fees for the instruction of these pupils and suggest that such children should enroll in the Elementary Correspondence School, conducted under the auspices of the Provincial Department of Education.

Inspector Barry, whilst not anxious to unduly increase the number of children in attendance at the Moricetown Indian Day School, considers that:

1. As Mr. Thistle, the father of the three children in question, is willing to pay any necessary fees for their education in the Moricetown Indian Day School, and,

2. In such a small community as Moricetown, which is almost wholly Indian, the good will of the Canadian National Railway foreman might be a distinct advantage to the Indians, and,

3. As there is no Provincial school within many miles of Moricetown,

the children in question might well be admitted to the Moricetown Indian Day School on the payment of $2 per

Dear Sir:

I am in receipt of your letter of the 25th instant with reference to the building that has been secured for school purposes on the Noricetown Reserve. It is noted that the rent will be at the rate of $12.00 a month and that a voucher will be forwarded by the Agent at the end of each quarter.

Dear Sir:

I would refer to your letter of November 19th, file 151-0-1, regarding the new Indian Day School at Moricetown, and beg to forward herewith a copy of a letter from Indian Agent Mortimer, together with the agreement to which he refers. The form required by the Department and the Treasury Board has been completed by Miss Sargent and accompanies this communication.

It will be noted that the total rental chargeable to the Department is $12.00 per month instead of $13.00, as was first estimated, and also that the Department will not be called upon to bear any expense in connection with furnishing the teacher's residence, with the exception of that involved in supplying a plain kitchen table.

Yours faithfully,

D. M. Mackay,
Indian Commissioner for B.C.

Encl.
D.M./AC

R. A. Hoey, Esq.,
Supt. of Welfare and Training,
Indian Affairs Branch,
Department of Mines and Resources,
Ottawa, Ont.
Dear Sir,

re - Moricetown Indian Day School.

I am in receipt of your letter of 4th January and wish to advise you that Miss Sargent opened the Indian Day School at Moricetown, B.C., on January 10th - as soon as possible following her appointment as teacher.

The desks arrived on January 15th and have been installed in the school. As the shipment has not been checked, owing to impassable roads, I do not know whether the two tables, asked for by wire, were included in the shipment.

It has been found unnecessary to purchase a heater for the school and a stove for the teacher's residence, these being provided by the Lessor. The Lessor, Tyee David, has built a very suitable, large room at the back of the school building for use as a residence for the teacher which the latter finds satisfactory. I am therefore not renting the cottage marked "C" in Captain Barry's report.

The rent for school and residence combined is twelve dollars ($12.00) per month. I am enclosing an agreement, in duplicate, to this effect which, no doubt, you will forward to Ottawa.

The teacher has provided her own bed, bedding, dishes, pots, pans, cutlery etc., and no further furnishings are required with the exception of the two tables above mentioned.

Your obedient servant,

GCM/SM.

Encls.

D. M. MacKay, Esq.,
Indian Commissioner for B.C.,
P.O.Box 8, Vancouver, B. C.

G. C. Mortimer,
Indian Agent.

Hazelton, B.C., March 5, 1947

Major D. M. McKay, Indian Commissioner for B.C., Vancouver, B.C.

While at Moricetown recently I found that the lean-to roof at the back of the school and the roofing on the teacherage are in urgent need of repair. The lean-to roof would require new supports and should be jacked up and new joists put under it requiring about 200 linear feet of two by four's. The teacherage requires application of two rolls of roofing paper. I asked Mr. Max Hedman, a carpenter, husband of the school teacher, to submit an estimate on the work. He offers to do the work on a contract basis at $35.00 including supplying material. While we do not own these buildings, the rent we pay for them, $12 a month, is very small. I would therefore recommend that we assume responsibility for these minor repairs.

J.J. Boys,
Indian Agent.

I enclose herewith a requisition from Mrs. A.C. Buddrus, teacher of the Moricetown Indian Day School who requires cooking utensils and furnishings as listed.

This Teacherage which we rent from a Moricetown Indian is very poorly furnished and I would recommend favourable consideration of the items requested. A quotation from a Hazelton Store is enclosed. I have inspected the goods upon which the quotation is submitted and consider they are quite satisfactory.

In order to make it livable this teacherage requires also paper and the ceilings and walls should be given a coat of Casein Paint and the woodwork trim should receive two coats of oilpaint. Materials required for this are 800 feet of Building Paper, 10 packages of Casein Paint and two quarts of white paint. The paints are obtainable locally but the Building Paper is not.

Reference to your files will show that upon taking over this building in March, 1944 the Department spent a sum of $364.27 to put it in order. This was to be debited from the rental at the rate of $7.50 per month until fully paid for. From this it will be seen that payment will not have been completed until June, 1948, but I would recommend that we undertake these small additional improvements, particularly because Mr. Buddrus the teacher's husband, a carpenter, is home at present and would willingly do the work without charge.

J.W. Boys,
Indian Agent.

I am forwarding Mr. Indian Agent Boys' letter of February 23rd and requisition for furnishings and cooking utensils for the Moricetown Indian Day School teacherage. The items requested are immediately available locally, with the exception of the spring-filled mattress, at an approximate cost of $125.00 and if the Department has funds available I would recommend that authority be granted for the purchase of these items.

With respect to the mattress, although one is available locally at a cost of $55.50 it is thought that a suitable mattress can be secured in Vancouver for approximately $30.00 and I would recommend that purchase of this item in Vancouver be authorized.

You will note also Mr. Boys' reference to the need for redecorating the teacherage. The materials required for this work will cost not more than $30.00 and the necessary labour will be provided by the teacher's husband without charge. The Moricetown Indian Day School is 20 miles from the nearest settlement at Smithers. On several occasions recently I have received complaints from Mrs. Buddrus, the teacher, regarding the conduct of Indians during night hours. There is no telephone within two miles although the Smithers-Hazelton line goes within 200 feet of the Teachorage. I feel that Mrs. Buddrus would be safer if she were in a position to contact the Police and for this purpose I recommend installation of a telephone at the Teachorage. The installation charge would be $2.50. Additional charges would be $2.30 per month rental plus the toll charges.

This installation, if permitted, would greatly facilitate administration of affairs at the very backward Moricetown Reserve. I would recommend departmental approval.

Contract forms are enclosed herewith.

Re: Proposed Telephone Installation
Moricetown Reserve

I am forwarding Supt. Boys' letter of June 14th and Telephone Contract referred to therein in connection with the proposed installation of a telephone in the Moricetown Indian day school teacherage.

While I am familiar with the Department's policy in connection with the installation of telephones in teacherages, involving payment of the initial installation cost by the Department and subsequent rental by the teacher, in this case in view of the isolated location of the village, the absence of white residents in the near vicinity and the infrequent mail service, I feel that the installation of a telephone apart from any security it might provide for the teacher would, as suggested by Mr. Boys, be of considerable assistance to his administration and might also obviate the necessity of occasional journeys to the village.

I would recommend that the Department approve the installation and payment of installation and rental charges for a period of six months at which time the matter should be reviewed by the Agent with a view to determining whether the expenditure is warranted.

W. S. Arneil,

Memorandum:

DEPUTY MINISTER

Moricetown Indian Day School
Chehalis Indian Day School

Included in our Main Estimates for 1950-51 are the following three projects in the Province of British Columbia:

Moricetown - Babine Agency - two-room school/residence - $35,000.
Chehalis - New Westminster Agency
- two-room school/residence - $35,000.
Kispiox - Babine Agency - teachersage - $10,000.

Whereas in other provinces we have met with considerable success in our day school building programme, such has not been the case in British Columbia. For example, at Bella Coola on the west coast of Vancouver Island, we advertised for tenders for the erection of a two-room school and attached teachers' residence and the lowest tender for standard construction was $42,612. The same school has been built by the Department in Saskatchewan for $29,000. We finally erected a quonset school at Bella Coola.

Therefore, due to the scarcity of contractors bidding on our projects and the high prices tendered by them, our officials in British Columbia came to the decision that prefabricated schools should be erected on the reserves listed above. Their decision in this regard has been due to the satisfaction obtained from the company which erected a two-room school and teachersage at Pemberton Meadows in the New Westminster Agency and a one-room school at...
Netlakatla in the Skeena River Agency. This company is Prefabricated Structures, Limited, Post Office Box 489, Vancouver, British Columbia, and I attach photographs of the Pemberton Meadows school taken by Inspector Davey.

We are now erecting three such prefabricated schools in the Skeena River Agency and our officials in British Columbia have now recommended the purchase of two more such schools and one teachersage. You will be interested in the following comments concerning our prefabricated school at Netlakatla, submitted by Mr. Indian Superintendent Anfield, under whose supervision the present three schools are being erected:

"I am satisfied that it will wear well, operate economically and that the type of construction is suitable and most adaptable for the type of country in the Skeena Agency. The school has been viewed with considerable approval by the Provincial School Inspector, Mr. J. Shell, at Prince Rupert. It is recommended that two-classroom schools of this type, with teachersages attached, be constructed at Hartley Bay, Greenville and Kincolith, with the least possible delay."

Mr. Arnell, the Indian Commissioner, feels that these buildings are quite satisfactory and points out that they can be erected at a cost considerably less than we could get through standard construction. He also points out that the erection of these schools will provide employment for the Indians as much of the work involved is ordinary labour.

The only other company in British Columbia producing schools of this type is Precision Housing Company, which produce pre-cut schools. These are much more difficult to erect with the type of semi-skilled Indian labour we will have available and are, therefore, not recommended by our field officials. We already have in mind a foreman carpenter who would supervise the erection of these prefabricated schools during the coming summer.

- Therefore
Therefore, I would recommend to you the following action:

(a) Approval of the submission to Council attached hereto covering the purchase of two prefabricated two-room schools with attached teacherages,

(b) Approval from the Minister for the purchase of a teacherage for the Kispiox Reserve at a cost of $2,764. (I attach a requisition for signature by the Minister and passing to the Departmental Purchasing Agent for this latter building).
