Dear Sir:

Whilst visiting the Babine mission at the late date and looking around I came to the conclusion that it will be time to appeal to the Government to establish an Indian School at the little village of Old Fort.

We have there quite a number of families that are settled down and have more or less adapted the white man's way of living and making a living. We have a number of children of school age and they are most anxious of getting the benefit of an education.

I have spoken with His Excellency Bishop E. M. Buenoz, O.M.I., who was highly in favour of the project. I therefore would like to further ask you to put this matter before the Government so that those people who come more and more in contact with white people will receive the benefit of an Education.

With best wishes, I beg to remain dear Sir.

I beg to enclose herewith a letter received from the Rev. Father Godfrey - apparently approved of by His Lordship Rev. E. M. Bunoz - with reference to the establishment of an Indian Day School at Old Fort Babine.

During my recent visit to the Babine Lake Reserves I carefully investigated the necessity of a day school at this point and have no hesitation in saying that it is necessary. There are approximately 25 children of school age at Old Fort and the nearest school is that at Fort Babine, about 40 miles distant.

During the month of September each year, whilst the Indians are fishing North of the Fort Babine Reserve, a few Old Fort children attend the Fort Babine Indian Day School, this being the only tuition they receive.

The Indians of Old Fort are very anxious to have their children educated and they have offered a suitable building to be rented for the purpose. I have no doubt a residence may also be obtained for a teacher.

May I respectfully suggest that this matter receive the consideration of the Department, which I strongly recommend.

THE DEPUTY MINISTER:

Re: Establishment of Old Fort Babine Indian Day School, Babine Agency, British Columbia

For the past three years the Indian Agent for the Babine agency, British Columbia has urged upon the Department the necessity of operating a day school at Old Fort Babine reserve.

In preparing our estimates for the current fiscal year, provision was made for the salary of a teacher at this place.

In order to comply with Section 9 (a) of the Indian Act, it is necessary to obtain an Order-in-Council establishing this school. I, therefore, enclose Memo to Council for this purpose.

Director.
AT THE GOVERNMENT HOUSE AT OTTAWA
Tuesday, the 28th day of June, 1938.

PRESENT:

HIS EXCELLENCY
THE GOVERNOR GENERAL IN COUNCIL:

WHEREAS the Minister of Mines and Resources reports that there are twenty-five (25) Indian children of school age at Old Fort Babine, in the Babine agency, Province of British Columbia, for whom at present no educational facilities are provided; and

That funds are available in the appropriation for the fiscal year 1938-39, Vote 168, for the establishment of a day school at Old Fort Babine;

NOW, THEREFORE, His Excellency the Governor General in Council, on the recommendation of the Minister of Mines and Resources and in accordance with the provisions of Section 9 (a) of the Indian Act, Chapter 95, R.S.C. 1927, is pleased to order that a day school, to be known as "The Old Fort Babine Indian Day School", be established at Old Fort Babine, in the Babine agency, Province of British Columbia, and it is hereby established accordingly.

Dear Sir:

Though I did not receive a copy of Departmental letter 151-9A-1 of July 4th last I did have a copy from Indian Agent Mortimer of his reply S-1-59 of July 15th and from this understand that authority has been given for the establishment of an Indian Day School in rented buildings at Old Fort Babine, Babine Agency.

I am forwarding herewith a copy of a letter I have received from His Excellency Bishop Bunoz of Prince Rupert.

I have discussed the matter with Inspector Barry and learn that of the candidates suggested by the Bishop the only one he is prepared to recommend is Miss M. Thorne Hughes of Victoria, who has been for the past few years teacher of the Songhees Indian Day School, Cowichan Agency.

It would appear that Miss Mary Bell accepted a Provincial appointment some time ago, and Captain Barry has not heard from Miss Moriaux for at least a year. At that time there was some doubt if Miss Moriaux would be given a B.C. certificate as she had to qualify in certain subjects. Captain Barry informs me that while he did instruct Miss Bell to apply to Bishop Bunoz as he himself had nothing to do with the nomination of teachers for vacant positions, he is not prepared to recommend the appointment of this girl even if available as she has had some difficulty with parents and children in the matter of too severe discipline while she taught in a Provincial School. Miss Wadel taught for us at the Inkameep and Sliammon Indian Day Schools in the past. She has no B.C. Certificate, though she has a Summer School qualification in Primary Work. Nothing is known here of Mr. Leonard J. Burns who would not appear to have a B.C. Certificate in any case.

Under the circumstances I would agree with our Inspector of Schools that probably Miss Mary Thorne Hughes is the best of these candidates, and I would therefore recommend that she be given the appointment.
Miss Mary Thorn Hughes is living with her parents at 1259 Richardson Street, Victoria, B.C. She is now some 25 years of age. Trained at the Victoria Normal School Miss Hughes holds an Interim First Class Certificate in British Columbia. Inspector was not able to recommend that this Interim Certificate be made permanent when last reporting to the Provincial Department of Education, and the present certificate is being allowed to remain in force for the present.

Miss Hughes was appointed teacher of the Songhees School on the nomination of the Bishop of Victoria in September 1936. This teacher has attended the Provincial Summer School on several occasions and has qualifications in Art and other subjects. She resigned in July 1938 more or less on the advice of the Inspector as the Indian parents were not quite satisfied. Captain Barry hoped to be able to arrange for a transfer to another Indian Day School, but all the candidates suggested to fill the vacancies were so highly qualified that he has not been able to place Miss Hughes.

I have met Miss Hughes, who is a very nice quiet well behaved girl, anxious to follow the advice of the Inspector of Schools and other Departmental officials, and I am attaching a copy of a letter which she wrote to Captain Barry a few days ago. This letter indicates that she is available and anxious to go to any Indian school even in a remote part of the Province.

None of the candidates would appear to be very well qualified; but as Captain Barry is anxious that Miss Hughes is given another chance of qualifying for her Permanent Provincial Certificate I would recommend that she be appointed on a temporary basis in the first instance.

Dear Sir,

re - Teacher for Old Fort Day School.

Since receiving School Inspector Barry's letter of September 12th I have given serious thought to the question of the appointment by the Department of a lady teacher to the Old Fort Babine Indian Day School.

Having always had a strong opinion that male teachers should be appointed to all isolated reserve schools, I have sent a night message to you today which reads as follows:

"Vancouver advises appointment female teacher Old Fort Babine School STOP Extremely anxious regarding lady's safety as reserve completely isolated and fifty miles from other Whites STOP Fully expected male teacher and arrangements made accordingly STOP If lady teacher sent complete furnishing Indian house necessary will Department provide requisites Wire reply."

When in conversation, some months ago, with the Rev. Father Godfrey, Priest to the Babine Lake Indians, who resides at Fort Babine some thirty miles away by water, I stressed the point that a male teacher should be recommended by the Bishop for this school. On my visit to the Babine Lake Reserves this month I was informed by the Priest that a male teacher had been recommended by Bishop Bunoz and I therefore made all necessary arrangements for his installation.

I may say there are no white people on this reserve and, apart from the two or three Whites at Fort Babine, there are no white settlers nearer than Topley, some fifty miles away.

There are one or two Indians of questionable character on this reserve, one of whom served eighteen months for an indecent assault on an Indian woman several years ago.

As I feel strongly in this matter may I ask if you will kindly reconsider this question and substitute a male teacher for the Old Fort School? However, should the Department send in the lady teacher appointed, will the Department provide all the necessary furnishings needed for her residence in an unfurnished Indian house? The most necessary articles required would be: cook-stove, heater, table, chairs, lamps, bed, crockery, pans, cutlery, washing and cleaning materials, etc.

As an escort is leaving here on the morning of September 29th any further instruction by telegram would be appreciated.

Your obedient servant,

Dear Major MacKay:

With reference to Departmental air mail letter 151-9A-1 of the 29th instant, in the matter of the re-establishment of an Indian Day School at Old Fort Babine, Babine Agency, I would report as follows:

Mr. Indian Agent Mallinson, in a letter S-1J-135, dated July 5, 1940, states that many of the Indians at Old Fort Babine take their families at the beginning of the hunting season to their traplines, returning about the middle of December. Apparently after Christmas the families of these trappers remain for some months in the village.

Mr. Mallinson further states that an Indian Day School at Old Fort Babine could be operated with success from January 1st to May 31st.

The monthly attendance at the Old Fort Babine Indian Day School has in the past been as follows:

| Month    | 1938-39 | 1939-40 |
|----------|---------|---------|
| October  | 12.3    | 8.10    |
| November | 9.5     | 6.52    |
| December | 13.47   | 10.21   |
| January  | 13.66   | 15.32   |
| February | 9.53    | 9.70    |
| March    | 9.26    | 9.07    |
| April    | 10.27   | 10.96   |
| May      | 9.18    | 9.75    |
| June     | 6.90    |         |
| July     | 10.79   |         |

It is obvious from the information given by Mr. Indian Agent Mallinson that if the Indian Day School be re-established at Old Fort Babine, it should be on the basis of a five month seasonal school, operated from January 1st to May 31st yearly.

It should, I think, be remembered that in a Departmental letter you were informed that the Department
had decided not to operate seasonal schools in the north, due to the need for strict economy. I am very doubtful that the average attendance in the past would warrant the establishment of even a seasonal school at Old Fort Babine.

The Department does not own any building at Old Fort Babine and if it is decided to establish a seasonal school at that point, it will be necessary to rent accommodation both for the school and for the teacher.

In Departmental letter 151-9A-1 of August 28th, quoted above, it is stated that His Excellency Bishop Bunoz has nominated Miss Catherine Finan for the post of teacher at Old Fort Babine. No information whatever is given with regard to the qualifications of the above named person who is quite unknown to me. I may say, however, that I am very strongly opposed to the appointment of single ladies at such out of the way schools.

Finally, I may say that I regret that under war conditions necessitating strict economy, it is impossible for me to recommend the establishment of even a seasonal school at Old Fort Babine.

Yours very truly,

Dear Sir:

I have to refer to your airmail letter of the 29th ultimo, your file 159-9A-1, regarding the Old Fort Babine Indian Day School. The question of reopening this school has been carefully discussed with Capt. Barry, whose letter to me of August 31st in the matter is enclosed.

If the school is to be operated at all, it should be on a five months' basis, but as the Department has already informed this office that owing to lack of funds it was found necessary to close a number of these seasonal schools, there could hardly be much justification to open this one, especially in view of the low average attendance.

In view of the unfortunate experience we have had with the last single young woman who taught at the Old Fort School, I consider the Department would be well advised to insist on the appointment of a male teacher, if and when the school is opened.

Under existing conditions and in view of the small attendance and Inspector Barry's report, I can not see that we would be justified in opening the Old Fort Babine School at the present time. The matter could come under review again should there be reasonable assurance of a substantial increase in attendance. In the meantime I would recommend that no action be taken to reopen this school.

Yours faithfully,

D. M. MacKay,
Indian Commissioner for B.C.

Right Reverend Sir:

I desire to refer to Your Lordship's letter of the 22nd ultimo and official reply of the 29th ultimo, with reference to the Old Fort Babine Indian Day School.

The attendance at this school has been very small and consequently does not justify us in re-opening it at the present time. If we were opening the school we would have to insist on a male teacher as it is considered undesirable to send in a female teacher to this isolated place.

In view of the above, I regret that favourable consideration cannot be given to the employment of Miss Finan. This school will remain closed for the current academic year, but if the number of children increases during the next year the Department will be prepared to consider operating it for the academic year 1941-42.

I refer to Mr. Neary's letter of November 1st concerning the provision of school facilities at Old Fort in the Babine Agency as included on our priority list submitted to the Department some time ago.

This point is located on Babine Lake about 30 miles S.E. of Fort Babine. A school survey indicates that there are 79 children 6 years of age and under at this point. Of this number 46 are in the age group 6 to 16. The pre-school age population is 33. Although the number of school age children would appear to warrant the construction of a two room school, due to the nomadic life of many of the families it is felt that a one room would probably meet the actual need.

I might say that a school was operated at this point up until March of 1940 when the present teacher at Fort Babine was transferred from Old Fort. At the time of his transfer there were 23 pupils enrolled in the Old Fort School, with an average attendance of 11.3. The school apparently remained closed, partly because of the acute teacher shortage.

The building in use was an old structure rented from one of the natives belonging to the reserve. It is quite unsuitable for school purposes and is in very poor repair.

Re: teacher's residence, Old Fort Babine, B.C.

Dear Sir:

I have for acknowledgment your letter of the 27th ultimo and also a lease relating to the occupancy of a new log house, that might be used as a teacher's residence, attached thereto.

Your recommendation that this house be rented as a teacher's residence at a rental of $60.00 per annum is acceptable to the Department and approved. I would suppose that such a lease, in order to be valid, would have to be approved by Order-in-council. I am anxious to know, therefore, if it would not be agreeable to rent this house from year to year, avoiding the necessity of signing or approving the terms of the lease.

Dear Sir:

re - Teacher's House at Old Fort, B. C.

I enclose, for the approval of the Department, a lease on a new log house built at Old Fort, for the teacher of the Indian Day School there, at a rental of $60.00 per annum.

The house is well built and has been erected under the supervision of Miss Mary Thorne Hughes, teacher of the Old Fort Indian Day School.

As the Rev. A. Godfrey, O.M.I., is in urgent need of his house, occupied by Miss Hughes until July 31st, I am dating the term of the attached lease from August 1st, so that the furnishings provided by the Department may be transferred to the new house.

I have purposely omitted the term in years in the lease and would suggest, as the house has been specially built as a teacher's residence, that the period be for five years, with the option of a further term at the expiration of same. May I kindly ask if this has the Department's approval?

Your obedient servant,

Ottawa, March 20, 1946.

Mr. S. Mallinson, Indian Agent, Hazelton, B.C.

On your voucher No. 444, $15.00 rent for teacher's house at Old Fort for quarter ended March 31st, has been brought to my attention.

I presume you refer to Old Fort Babine. This school has been closed for some time and it is difficult for me to understand why you have been forwarding vouchers for the rent of a teacher's residence. Please let me have an explanation. The voucher is being returned unpaid.

Philip Phelan,
Chief, Training Division.
Indian Affairs Branch, Department of Mines & Resources, Ottawa.

Your File: 151-94-5

In reply to your letter of March 20th, I wish to advise that when the School at Old Fort Babine was opened, a teacher's residence was rented from Casimel Emil Williams and some furniture, complete bed, stove, table and chairs etc., were provided by the Department. On the closing of the School in May 1940, all desks and equipment from the School building were transferred to the teacher's residence where Department property is stored. Since that time the teacher's residence has been constantly used by the Field Matron at Babine during her visits to Old Fort, and on occasions by myself and the Police when visiting the Babine Lake Reserves. Mrs. Earwick, the Field Matron and I are the only ones possessing a key to the house.

In my letter of May 30th, 1940 to the Indian Commissioner for B.C., the following was a part:

"All school equipment at Old Fort was transferred from the school building to the teacher's residence, thereby vacating the school building."

I am therefore returning Voucher #444 in favour of the Indian owner of the teacher's residence for payment of the quarterly rent of $15.00, the amount which is most necessary the Department assume.

S. Mallinson,
Indian Agent.

My dear Captain,

To my own great satisfaction and I feel sure also to yours, I have obtained the promise of a man who fills all the conditions demanded by the Department to undertake the work of teacher at Kitwancool. His name is Norman Green and he has been a most successful teacher at Kincolith. He is fully qualified and can do something in the way of Manual Training, is a good musician, healthy and young. He is to be married this summer to a young woman who is trained in domestic science and understands something of nursing.

It is the finest combination in the Diocese and they will be ready to go in to Kitwancool in September. I know you have in hand the providing of a building for a school and a house to live in. I believe the Department also makes it a point to equip the school with everything necessary and supplies the necessary heavy furniture for the house.

Mr. Green has been getting $100.00 per month for ten months per year, so I hope the Department will do the best they can for him in this new and difficult field. Such matters as these I, of course, must leave with you. Mr. Green is writing you and you will probably receive his letter along with mine.

Do you think it possible to get something for Mrs. Green as Field Matron, especially as she is trained in domestic science and nursing?

I have not been so pleased for a long time as I am in securing the services of such excellent people and I am most anxious to have them made contented by their reception and treatment. I have known you long enough to be sure that you will do all possible for them.

Dear Sir:

Mr. Collison paid a visit to this village Saturday night and brought me your letter. I was surprised to find out that you had not received my first letter—I cannot imagine what became of it, for it was mailed here on May 23rd.

Since it was written in the form of an application for the position of teacher at Kitwancool, I will briefly state my qualifications: I am a graduate of the Victoria Normal School and hold a First Class Teaching Certificate for the Province of British Columbia. I have had four years' teaching experience, two years in Provincial Rural Schools, one year (1936-37) in the Indian Residential School at Elkhorn, Manitoba, and for the past year I have been teaching here (Kincolith).

I hold a Strathcona Trust Physical Training Certificate and a St. John's Ambulance First Aid Certificate. I have had a good musical training and am quite proficient on the piano or organ. I can give lessons on these instruments. While here I have assisted the Church choir in their work.

I am very much interested in the welfare, moral, spiritual, and material, of the Indians, particularly the young. I will do all in my power to help the people of Kitwancool. As you advised, I will postpone my proposed visit to Kitwancool, and am leaving on today's boat for my holidays. My address will be Norman Green, P.O. Box 58, Fernie, B.C. I will most surely call on Capt. Barry while in Vancouver, as I had already intended to. I hope you have already communicated with the Department regarding Kitwancool and please let me know as what you hear as soon as possible.

If my appointment is certified by the Department I will be getting married in August. My fiance has been employed at the Elkhorn Indian School for the past five years and has worked in all the various positions filled by lady staff members. She has at times assisted the nurse and taken over part of her duties when the nurse has been away. She would be a great asset to an Indian village.
When you write I would be very pleased if you would give me what information you can regarding a house available and whether or not it would be partly furnished.

Thanking you very kindly for all you may do, I will now close, trusting that I will hear from you again soon.

Very truly yours,

"Norman Green."

Your Honour:

We, the children of the Great White Empire, retain affectionate memories of the Great Queen Victoria, and our ever to be remembered King Edward and King George the Fifth.

We, the Natives of this Great Province, wish to assure you of our loyalty to His Majesty King George the sixth, of whom we are dutiful and humble subjects, and we feel sure that while your Honour is his Representative you will render us your helping hand, that we children of the Crown may be more civilized, we therefore humbly set forth our prayers to your Honour.

Whereas it is desirable that the Indians of Kitwancool, resident of the trapping lines in the County of Prince Rupert, B.C., should stand united, and act in concert in all matters affecting our general interests,

and whereas for such purpose it is advisable to set forth our humble prayers that your Honour may authorize to register our trap-lines in one, and in the name of our proposed organization, namely, "The Kitwancool Trappers Association" and to sub-divide the interior of the same one registration, to each individual;

and that only members of the Kitwancool Trappers Association to have the rights to trap on the said one trap-line or registered area.

Your Honour we beg to inform you that we have been united for a number of years and we therefore humbly desire your Honour to inform us of the proper procedure to follow, to obtain our desires.

Your Honour we know that the Game Act is the authority but our desires is not provided therein.

Therefore we humbly pray your Honour to render us your assistance in order that we may have our humble desires legally established.

We humbly pray your Honour to consider our humble prayers herein, since the Indian Trapping matters are vested in the authority of the British Columbia Government.

We wish Your Honour every blessing and success from our heavenly Father.

Honourable Gentlemen,

Whereas it is desirable that the Kitwancool Indians should be progressive and to maintain our traditions of service and loyalty to the Crown, as desired in His Excellency's, The Governor General's letter, under date of the 17th July, 1919, which reads as follows:

"I am desired by His Excellency the Governor General to acknowledge your resolution of the 2nd July.

The loyalty of the Indians of Canada to the Crown was manifested during the Great War in which many of them were killed and in which they distinguished themselves in many ways. His Excellency was very glad to receive the expression of loyalty from your group of British Columbia Indians, and trusts that you will continue to progress and to maintain your traditions of Service and Loyalty."

We therefore humbly set forth our prayers and our humble petition which reads as follows:

1st. Whereas the Kitwancool Indians have been self-supporting people, from time immemorial and later become isolated people having no connection with all the other Indian tribes along the Skeena and Nass Rivers, therefore we, the Kitwancoolers, or Kitwancoolians, humbly pray The Dominion Government, not to connect the Kitwancool Affairs, with the said "Indian Affairs", and further, we humbly pray that the Dominion Government, to deal especially separately with regards the Kitwancool Affairs, beginning September 1938, A.D.

2nd. That we, as Kitwancoolers, may not be furnished with free Medicine, Seeds, Hospital, Plows, Cattle and other implements, which is always furnished to all other Indians, to whom the Kitwancoolians, have never been in company or connected.

Dear Sir:

I am enclosing petition to the Department of Indian Affairs, said to be on behalf of the Kitwancool Band, in the Babine Agency. This petition, as you see, deals with a request for higher education.

I might point out to the Department that this Band have only just been supplied with a new school, and as far as higher education is concerned, if it should turn out to be advisable, which I doubt, it is a matter that can be dealt with at a later date. They also state in this petition that they want to be self-supporting, and I am sure the Department will not object to this.

Inspector Pragnell informs me that these Indians are very fond of long-winded petitions, particularly the so-called president and vice-president, and as you know they have given considerable trouble in the past. However, they are a fairly energetic Band, though the Chief and Councillors are rather inclined to be self-important. If the Department sees fit to answer this petition, through the Indian Agent, I should suggest that they be informed that the Department is pleased to hear that they do not wish to be a charge on the Government, and that the matter of higher education can only be taken up when these Indians show fitness for it, and when money is available, but it naturally means that they will have to use existing institutions for that purpose. To build and run such a one at Kitwancool, itself, would be too expensive and not reasonable, and a High School as suggested there would, unless there were large numbers, necessitate much expense.

Further, it might be pointed out that the younger Indians are by force of circumstances bound to return to the Reserves and

I desire to refer you to my memorandum of October 22, with reference to the re-appointment of Miss N. Skaftfeld as teacher of the above-noted school.

In my memorandum I stated that her re-appointment should be approved from October 12. More recent information indicates that she took over the school effective from October 1, 1945, and I would appreciate it if you would arrange to pay her from that date at the rate of $25.00 a teaching month, plus bonus. Her monthly cheque should be forwarded to the Bank of Montreal, Main Branch, Granville Street, Vancouver, B.C.

Director.

Dear Sir:

I am forwarding herewith a letter A-9 of October 24th received from Mr. Indian Agent Mallinson.

The purchase of an organ for the Kitwancool Indian Day School has been discussed with Inspector Barry who, due to the necessity for economy at the present time, is unable to recommend the purchase of the instrument suggested by the Indian Agent.

While I feel that this small school might be able make use of such an organ as the Indian Agent requests, I am not prepared to recommend expenditures of this nature during the present emergency. I should be glad, however, to have the Department's decision in the matter.

Yours faithfully,

D.M. MacKay,
Indian Commissioner for B.C.

The Secretary,
Indian Affairs Branch,
Department of Mines & Resources,
Ottawa, Ont.
Dear Sir,

re- Purchase of Organ for Kitwancool School.

Will you please advise if the Department would favourably consider the purchase of an organ for the Kitwancool Indian Day School? There is at present no musical instrument of any kind at the school and an organ would be of great assistance to the teacher.

I have made enquiries and have located a small organ at Woodwards Store, Edmonton, which could be easily transported to Kitwancool. The price on this instrument is $24.00, F.O.B. Kitwanga, to which amount should be added $5.00 for cartage from Kitwanga to Kitwancool.

Yours faithfully,

S. Mallinson,
Indian Agent.

D.M. MacKay, Esq.,
Indian Commissioner for B.C.,
P. O. Box 70, VANCOUVER, B.C.

Dear Sir:

I regret that due to present conditions the Department is not prepared to authorize the purchase of an organ.

Yours truly,

R.A. Hosey,
